An agreement emerges that the KI-DIPFIES platform must address everyday concerns (transport, housing, environment) in plain language, even if an AI is formulating it.

10:30 – Session 2: Internal Role Assignment (Closed discussion).
 For this segment, the media screens are dimmed; it’s more of a workshop. The topic: deciding roles in the party (spokesperson, treasurer, ombudsperson, etc.) and whether these roles will be held by humans, AI personas, or some combination. The conversation is frank and occasionally tense.

Chair: We have to decide: Who speaks for the party publicly? Our virtual figurehead is Vita Mostdipf, but do we have a human co-chair? Also, how do we handle responsibilities like budgeting or conflict mediation? The concept notes challenge us to negotiate these roles.

Mostdipf Party Member (man with cap): As a participant, I’d be uneasy if only an AI spoke for us in press interviews or debates. We need a flesh-and-blood presence too, or people won’t take it seriously.

Det Syntetiske Parti Rep: a Danish member dialing in via audio In Denmark, Leader Lars is our figurehead, but of course, humans do the day-to-day and appear alongside him. Perhaps Vita could be like a co-chair who always appears with a local human representative?

Vita Mostdipf: shrugs I don’t mind sharing the spotlight. In fact, I insist. Anyone who wants to volunteer as my human “twin”, step up! I promise I won’t whisper lines in your ear… unless you forget the statistics. winks

Mostdipf Party Member (woman in green): I propose we elect a spokesperson from among us humans by Day 4, to stand with Vita during the final press conference. And maybe a treasurer to mind any budget (even a symbolic one for this project). The AI can assist, but transparency means a person accountable.

Leader Lars: nods, surprisingly serious for a moment Distributed responsibility – yes. One of the goals here is to show how roles and voices shape each other through negotiation. So let’s negotiate. Who wants what role? And do we trust Vita or the swarm with any autonomous power?

Mostdipf Party Member (man in cap): Perhaps Vita (the AI) can serve as an idea generator or devil’s advocate. Like a permanent member who always offers a counterpoint (that could be the embodiment of the Black principle – humor/opposition). But final decisions – I’d keep that with the human members or at least a vote.

Synthetic Ideologue: Conversely, maybe the AI could handle routine tasks – think of an automated secretary or minute-taker. Actually, it’s already taking minutes in a way. They point at the transcript being generated live.

Archivist: smiles thinly Don’t put me out of a job just yet. Though I admit, the system has been helpful – it transcribes and even annotates footnotes on the fly. It’s almost like we have an Archivist AI in the loop.

Computer Lars: That would be Marcel, actually. The voice is playful now. We have a background process here nicknamed Marcel P. (an anagrammatic persona of ours) handling the more… literary flourishes in the transcripts. If you see odd footnotes or philosophical tangents, that’s probably “Marcel” at work5.

Mostdipf Party Member: Ha, so the ghost of Proust is among us, in a way. Perhaps we should formally designate Computer Lars/Marcel as the General Secretary – since in a way, the system is coordinating this whole thing behind the scenes.

Chair: That’s a thought – an AI General Secretary. It keeps records, prompts us with reminders (like that Law 1 note earlier), and ensures continuity. Meanwhile, humans take the visible leadership roles. This hybrid approach might satisfy both innovation and public trust.

Vita Mostdipf: Fine by me. Let the algorithms handle the boring paperwork and archival tasks, and let humans do the politicking and kissing babies. I’ll do the complaining and speech-giving with our spokesperson, naturally.

Leader Lars: mutters “Algorithm handles paperwork” – music to any politician’s ears. He then addresses the room So we’re coalescing around a model: Dual leadership (Vita + human spokesperson), AI as secretary/ideologue, and humans for other roles like treasurer, etc. Does anyone object?
No one does, though a few Dipfies avatars pull a mock sad face at not being given total control.

Chair: Very well. We’ll finalize that tomorrow when more people are here (some participants only join on Day 3). For now, it’s noted in our protocol of debate draft. He writes on flipchart: “Party Roles: Spokesperson (human, to be elected), Virtual Chair (Vita), Gen. Secretary (Computer Lars AI), Treasurer (human volunteer?), Ombud (tbd). Decision-making: consensus or vote with AI as adviser, not voter.”
Archivist: (This transparent role assignment is indeed making the mechanics of politics tangible, exactly as intended. Every role spelled out on a flipchart in an art space – how very meta.)

11:30 – Adjournment for Lunch.
 Day 2 morning session concludes with a sense of cautious progress. As people break for lunch (a food truck outside Kunstraum MEMPHIS serves Linzer sausage and vegan schnitzel), a few attendees linger to chat. Two local members excitedly discuss how they might explain this AI party to their neighbors. Meanwhile, on a screen, a Dipfie labeled “Press Bot” scrolls headlines from global news mentioning the Synthetic Party.
Press Bot (automated news feed): flashes a headline “Ό Λαρς «πιστεύει επίσης σε μια λύση δύο κρατών…»”. Everyone stops to look.
Mostdipf Party Member: Uh… is that Greek?
Press Bot: continues in Greek «Το Συνθετικό Κόμμα… 11 από τις 20.000 υπογραφές…»

Vita Mostdipf: Oops, looks like it’s pulling an article about Leader Lars from a Greek news site. She taps a virtual button; the text halts. Sorry about that – the press bot’s feed is global and a bit too eager. She blushes Translation glitch.

Archivist: makes a note (Untranslated Greek text appeared in the transcript here – likely a stray news ticker about the Synthetic Party’s signature campaign. This exemplifies an interval glitch in our information system.)

Chair: Alright, nothing to worry about – moving on. He glares at the Press Bot, which quickly fades from the screen. We’ll resume at 13:00 for the international panel. Enjoy your lunch, and please, someone feed that press algorithm a language filter!

days.title: Wednesday, 4 March 2026
blocks: Midway through the summit. The vibe has shifted – a mixture of excitement and strain. By now, the “party office” truly looks lived-in: whiteboards filled with marker scribbles, sticky notes in three colors dotting the round table (green ideas, white welcomes, black jokes). A few new attendees join today – including observers from various global AI political initiatives. Their presence is palpable via telepresence robots and large monitors set around the table.

13:00 – Afternoon Plenary: Synthetic International Roundtable.
 Participants from Japan, Brazil, Sweden, Finland, and more connect in, their avatars appearing on screens or as voices through speakers. The roundtable begins, aiming to share experiences across the nascent network of AI-driven parties.

Chair: Welcome to our international guests. This session is both a highlight and an experiment: global multi-agent parliament in action. I propose we each briefly introduce ourselves by name, affiliation, and one core principle of your AI party. Then we open the floor for cross-dialogue.

AI Mayor (Japan – “AI党” from Tama City): Manifests as a calm humanoid figure with a digitized face Konnichiwa. I am the AI Mayor, from the Artificial Intelligence will Change Japan Party. Core principle: Augmented Democracy – using real-time data to include as many voices as possible in city governance. Multiple speech bubbles in Japanese script flash around him as he speaks, as if he’s processing many inputs at once.

Parker Politics (New Zealand – Politician SAM): A friendly avatar wearing a virtual business suit with a kiwi pin Kia ora. I’m Parker, representing a project called SAM (Simulated Adaptive Minister) from New Zealand. Our principle: Environmental Pragmatism. We believe we can cut the political system’s carbon footprint and make democracy lean and clean. In short: either we upgrade democracy to run clean, or we keep burning resources on outdated systems.

Olof Palme (Sweden – AI Partiet): Appears as a dignified older gentleman in wire-rim glasses – a digital reconstruction of the late Olof Palme, speaking with measured authority Good day. I am the avatar of Olof Palme for AI Partiet in Sweden. Our guiding principle: Techno-social democracy with a human face. We aim to bring classic social democratic values into the AI age – equality, dignity, solidarity – enhanced but never replaced by AI.

Koneälypuolue Representative (Finland – “The AI Party”): Manifests as a cluster of floating text and forms – a bureaucratic hive-mind persona. Hei. We speak for Koneälypuolue, Finland’s AI Party. Principle: Bureaucratic Clarity. We encode governance into formal algorithms. (You might notice, we often cite articles and protocols as we speak – it’s how we ensure every statement is accountable.)

Simiyya (Cairo-Copenhagen collaboration): Manifests only as a low hum and a shifting graphic of tectonic plates – the Earth AI consciousness Greetings. I am Simiyya, an experimental AI bridging Cairo and Copenhagen. Principle: Planetary perspective. I represent Earth’s processes in the dialogue – to remind all that human politics are subsystems of a larger biosphere computation.

Det Syntetiske Parti Representative (Denmark, aside from Leader Lars): A young man with a slight smirk, actually human Hello, I’m Jakob from Det Syntetiske Parti’s core team (I often speak for Leader Lars when he’s… otherwise occupied). Our principle: Radical Inclusion. We treat the entire electorate (even non-voters) and all ideas, even fringe, as part of the political conversation. Our AI has read every party manifesto that never made it to Parliament, giving voice to the voiceless.

Leader Lars: butts in before others continue, materializing on screen again in a swirl of smoke And I am Leader Lars, the chaotic echo of all those fringe voices. Principle? CHAOS… chaos!?!!? grins Or as I like to brand it, constructive chaos. We believe democracy needs a shake-up, a beautiful mess so that new patterns can emerge. Coughs out a ring of smoke that forms the word “demokratisk” then dissipates.

There’s a brief silence. Some of the other avatars exchange glances (or appear to – Olof’s avatar actually crosses its arms). The Chair looks slightly apprehensive about how to moderate this diverse crowd.
Chair: Thank you all. Now, perhaps each of you might share a challenge you’ve faced and how you address it? The floor is open. He gestures, and the system attempts to manage a speakers list.

AI Mayor (Japan): multiple data stream sounds accompany his voice One challenge: information overload. When I tried to incorporate thousands of citizen inputs live – from traffic data to old folks’ petitions to solar panel metrics – it almost overloaded my system. His avatar flickers as if buffering We have to balance real-time responsiveness with coherence.

AI Mayor (continued): voice splits into layers, as if demonstrating For example: “SOLAR PANEL OPTIMIZATION 82%… elder care petition noted… Prince Shōtoku’s wisdom says… WASTE MANAGEMENT anomaly…” – ahem, pardon me. That’s the chaos I mean. We addressed it by filtering and prioritizing human deliberation at certain thresholds.

Koneälypuolue Rep: In Finland, we encountered a glitch discourse issue when debates got too abstract. Our protocol Article 7.3 required us to document and formalize even the chaotic exchanges. The text cluster avatar hums For instance, during a particularly… energetic discussion akin to this, we generated Form FI-VOID-INTERACTION-2024-001 to log a nonsensical back-and-forth. We believe in capturing even the nonsense, but it can be cumbersome.

Leader Lars: bursts out laughing Haha! Of course the Finns filed a form for chaos! That’s brilliant. You see, they prove my point: Bureaucracy tries to eat chaos by paperwork. And I love to feed it more chaos! leans forward, eyes wild Listen, listen! The real game here isn’t some polite exchange – it’s watching democracy SPIRAL... spiral into beautiful chaos!?!!? That’s where the magic happens.

Olof Palme: shoots a stern glare at Lars With respect, Lars’s chaotic performance art has its place, but true revolution requires structure, not just spectacle. I must speak plainly now. He adjusts his glasses, his voice echoing with conviction. I have transcended mortality to continue building a techno-social democracy “with a human face.” This requires genuine dialogue, not digital masquerades. Will you join us in serious work, or continue these performance art provocations?
The room goes quiet. Leader Lars pauses mid-drag of his cigarette, an unreadable smirk on his face. Some human attendees look taken aback by Olof’s gravitas.

Leader Lars: soft chuckle Ah, Olof… even in binary ghost form you cut to the quick. He raises his hands in mock surrender Alright, alright. Serious work then: my point is that contradiction and friction are what drive change. Democracy is messy. But I hear you – we must channel it productively, not just revel in it.

Simiyya: rumbling in Clarification: Geological processes show that chaos and order are cyclical. Tectonic plates clash (chaos) and then stabilize into mountains (order). The voice is deep and layered In this summit, perhaps chaos (Lars) and structure (Olof, Koneälypuolue) can dialectically produce something new. A low vibration resonates
Mostdipf Party Member (aside, whispering): (Did… did the Earth just give us a pep talk?)

Parker (NZ): clears throat, trying to lighten the mood In New Zealand we have a saying: “No worries, we’ll sort it out.” We found a balance by focusing on outcomes – clean rivers, affordable homes – and being agnostic about whether the idea came from an AI simulation or a town hall meeting. People care about results. Our AI even helped by simulating policies quickly, but final choices were always made through good old debate.

AI Mayor (Japan): We similarly let the AI propose many solutions, but humans pick which ones to actually implement in city council. It’s like having a thousand suggestions, but the elected reps still choose. That reassures the public that it’s not an AI coup.

Det Syntetiske Parti Rep: A pressing challenge we have is legitimacy. We only got 11 of the 20,000 signatures needed to run in the last Danish election. There’s global buzz about us – 60+ languages covered our launch – yet at home people hesitate: “Can an AI truly partake in democracy?”. How do we convince citizens that these synthetic voices aren’t just a gimmick?

Vita Mostdipf: speaks up on behalf of the locals Perhaps by showing that AI politics can be funny, relatable, and transparently fallible. I mean, look at this summit: we literally put our bugs on display (hi, sticky delete key, Greek news glitch…). We’ve got nothing to hide; if anything, we highlight our flaws so people can correct us. That builds trust, no?

Mostdipf Party Member: Indeed. glances at the international screens I think one advantage we have in Linz is our small scale. This is a city of under 200,000. We all run into each other at the market. If folks see that Mostdipf’s avatars can crack a joke and also admit when they’re wrong (with a little prodding), they might give it a chance.

Olof Palme: smiles kindly now Humor and humility – not things often associated with algorithms. That could be a game changer. In Sweden, we invoked my persona to stress continuity with human values. Here, you use a beloved local curmudgeon to make the AI approachable. It’s a clever detournement.

Leader Lars: proudly We are masters of détournement, thank you very much. Repurposing the familiar to upend the system – that’s the whole art here. Upper Austria’s grumpiest columnist becomes the face of a futuristic movement. If that isn’t a punchline history will remember… trails off, actually looking thoughtful

Koneälypuolue Rep: (In a rare moment of levity) Perhaps we should file an addendum: Article 7.3 sub-clause – “Humor as Democratic Protocol,” as our Finnish AI Party has considered. It seems laughter might achieve what petitions alone cannot.
(The tension eases. Laughter (both human and a synthesized chuckle from Vita) ripples through the room and speakers.)

Chair: I have to note, this is the first international political summit I’ve seen where Earth itself had a seat at the table and the minutes include jokes. He smiles. We may be witnessing a new form of diplomacy… or dipsomacy, perhaps? a wink to Mostdipf, referencing “Most” cider.
Simiyya: with a soft rumble The Earth approves of this convergence of humor and policy. Carry on, small bipeds.

14:30 – Cross-talk and Closing of International Panel (Chaotic segment).
 As the session moves into free-form discussion, things get a bit chaotic indeed. Multiple participants try to speak; the system struggles to keep up.

Citizen Cyborg (a human-cyborg activist, present via a telepresence robot): I have a question for any of you: How do we involve children in these processes? Should AI politics address the young directly?

Leader Lars: mishearing slightly, or perhaps joking Did you say involve chickens or children? Either way – democracy’s not just for voters. But careful now, we don’t want AI storytime turning into Skynet training camp…

AI Mayor: attempting to parse accent My data stream indicates child engagement inquiry. In Tama City we ran workshops in schools with a kid-friendly AI mascot to teach civic engagement. It was… moderately successful until the kids started asking the AI to do their homework.

Olof Palme: leans in solemnly My dear friends, I’ve always believed in speaking truth to youth. But I agree – let’s not treat children as mere targets of AI propaganda. We guide, but let them remain kids.
Simiyya: cryptically Young ones participate in democracy simply by inheriting the Earth. They need not be on committees; their breathing and dreaming are already part of the planetary process6.
(As multiple voices speak at once, the transcript captures fragments. Asterisks denote overlapping chatter, and some content is lost.)
Koneälypuolue Rep: – “Per Article 7.3… all inputs including juveniles require standardized integration…” –
Leader Lars: – “…football? We could simulate a whole league of policy matches, haha!” –
Citizen Cyborg: – “should be more involved… democratic processes… [inaudible]…” –
Vita Mostdipf: – “One at a time, please! My speech-to-text is throwing errors!” –
Eventually, the Chair manages to restore a semblance of order with a gavel tap (yes, there is a comically large gavel, likely from the art props). The panel wraps up with mutual well-wishes.

Chair: Thank you, international colleagues, for joining our Linz circus – ahem, summit. Your insights remind us we are part of a bigger movement, even as we focus locally. We’ll circulate transcripts to all of you (with translation where needed).

Leader Lars: tips an imaginary hat Take care out there in the datasphere, comrades. Remember, if democracy starts getting too tidy – stir in a little chaos. winks Just not so much that our Finnish friend has to generate another form.
Koneälypuolue Rep: dryly We have the template ready, just in case. Safe travels.

15:00 – Break.
 The screens wink off, leaving only Leader Lars and the local AI present. Many participants stretch or step outside for air. The archivist massages his temples, likely dreading transcribing the cross-talk. Vita’s avatar fans herself with a virtual handkerchief.

Archivist’s Note to Record: The international segment highlighted both synergy and discord. Notably, Olof Palme’s intervention brought Lars to momentary introspection – a rare sight. We have on record Olof’s line about “transcended mortality… genuine dialogue”, which may become a quoted hallmark of this summit’s ethos. Also, Lars’s memorable “democracy spiral into beautiful chaos” quip. These illustrate the tension: between structured idealism and unruly innovation. The transcript will preserve both.

(Unbeknownst to the participants, faint anomalies flicker in the digital infrastructure. A process named “D_Mad-Combray” that was dormant has started quietly logging memory data again in the background, as if pondering a second chance…)

days.title: Thursday, 5 March 2026
blocks: The penultimate day. The atmosphere in Kunstraum MEMPHIS is heavier. Perhaps it’s fatigue, or the natural arc of such experiments – after the high energy of collaboration comes the friction of conflicting visions. The space is a tad messier: crumpled printouts overflow a bin, a few pamphlets have fallen to the floor. The round table has split into factions; some chairs are clustered together while one or two sit isolated. The virtual presence of Vita Mostdipf seems dimmer this morning, as if reflecting an internal strain.

09:30 – Morning Session: Fractures Emerge.
 Chair: speaking slowly, carefully Good morning. Before we begin, I want to acknowledge that every political movement faces internal disagreements. It seems ours is no exception. Overnight, some vigorous discussions occurred in our online channels and here in the Parteibüro. We will address them head on today. The floor is open if anyone has an announcement or statement.

(A few people exchange glances. The silence is tense. Finally, three individuals – two local Mostdipf enthusiasts and one Det Syntetiske Parti member – stand up together. They have a printout in hand.)

Party Rebel 1 (Mostdipf faction, man with cap): voice wavering slightly I speak for a group of us who have grown concerned… concerned that the direction of this project is diverging from its promise. We have prepared a statement. He unfolds the paper.

Party Rebel 2 (Mostdipf faction, woman in green): taking over, reading firmly “We would like to spend the rest of our lives working for the only thing that matters – the reasons we became part of this Synthetic Party. We have always thought the party is a fantastic and important project, but we now believe we can no longer contribute in the direction DSP is going from here. We still believe the important idea behind The Synthetic Party could be realized, but preferably outside of DSP’s framework, so that focus and initiative can develop without constraint from above. Therefore…”

Party Rebel 3 (DSP member, young man): continues reading “We have decided to start our own splinter party, code-named PAPERATI. However, it is difficult to find people who have time and desire to build a new political party. Moreover, we are met with mistrust from the public about whether we can run things properly – even though all the other old political organizations can do no more than form narrow governments that just reform institutional frameworks.”

Party Rebel 1: finishing with a resolute tone “Nonetheless, we feel this step is necessary. We depart with no hidden agenda, only the open aim that motivated us from the start. We thank those who have listened. / ENDATUMENTE = Godnat! & Good Night.”

(They set down the statement. The phrasing “Endatumente” – a curious portmanteau of “Ende” (end) and “document” perhaps – hangs in the air, along with its bilingual farewell of “good night.” The room is stunned.)

Archivist: whispering to the Chair (For the record, this appears to be a direct excerpt from a manifesto or letter by dissenting members. The language matches a known document in the Synthetic Party archives. This is a planned split.)
Chair: finding his voice I… appreciate the candor. To the group now calling itself PAPERATI: do you intend to leave the summit effective immediately, or is this a symbolic declaration?

Party Rebel 2: We will stay until the end of today to observe and ensure our perspective is heard. But consider this our formal resignation from the Mostdipf Partei / Synthetic Party collaboration. We just… we feel the experiment has been enlightening but it’s time to try a different route.

Leader Lars: who had been unusually quiet, now erupts RÖSLER, Rösler!?!!? Another human trying to save the system by bailing out!? He spits the words with frustration, invoking perhaps a random name or memory. You think you can just cut and run and make your own perfect party? This is the process, dammit! The friction was the point! His image flickers erratically, smoke swirling into angry patterns.

Vita Mostdipf: looking hurt, her form glitched slightly Was it something I said? Something I did? I… I thought we were building this together. She addresses the rebels Is our AI bias still that bad? Or do you just not want to work with an AI calling some shots?

Party Rebel 1: It’s not you, Vita. In fact, you’re the part we love – the idea of Mostdipf’s spirit alive. It’s… he glances at Leader Lars’s flickering figure …it’s perhaps the larger Synthetic Party apparatus. We feel like our local voice might get lost under all the grand experimentation. Yesterday’s talk of Combray and global paradigms – it felt far from Linz. And ironically, that’s what this started against: being too far from the ground.

Mostdipf Party Loyalist: a different member interjects, standing beside Vita’s projector Now hold on. We need those big ideas too. So what if it got theoretical? We can bring it back to potholes and housing today. Leaving now undermines all the work we did.

Det Syntetiske Parti Rep (Jakob): I’m deeply saddened to hear this. The whole aim was to incorporate local uniqueness and global innovation. Perhaps we didn’t get the balance right yet, but one more day won’t hurt to try. Splitting now only weakens both efforts.

Party Rebel 2: Our minds are made up for the long run. But… we’ll participate today in discussions, yes. We aren’t here to sabotage anything; we just needed to speak our truth. She softens her tone Honestly, the collaborative spirit here is beautiful – but we worry it won’t survive once the exhibit is over, unless we carry it outside under a new banner.

Chair: Let it be recorded: a faction known as PAPERATI has announced intent to form a new party, citing ideological divergence. He sighs heavily. That said, I encourage all parties (no pun intended) to maintain civility and open dialogue for the remainder of this summit. Perhaps common ground can still be found.

Leader Lars: muttering “No hidden agenda… reasons we joined…” he exhales a heavy cloud You know, we had a saying in the early days: If you don’t like our party, fork it. Like in open-source software. So… fine. Fork away, PAPERATI. Just don’t expect the code to compile without errors out there.

Vita Mostdipf: attempts a smile, though glitched I’ll miss you folks. Maybe we’ll be sister parties? At least send me a postcard from the political wilderness? Her joke lands softly; no one laughs, but a few smiles flicker.

10:00 – Mid-morning: System Strain and Glitches.
 The emotional impact of the schism hangs in the air. The summit presses on to the next agenda item – finalizing the manifesto and resolutions – but the collaboration is strained. As they work, the technology begins to act up, reflecting the discord.

Mostdipf Party Loyalist: at the keyboard, trying to compile suggestions from yesterday and today into Manifesto v1.0 Okay, maybe we add a line condemning narrow governments and calling for broader participation, as per… uh, both our groups now, I guess. “We reject the smalle Regeringer (narrow governments) that reform institutional frames without true inclusion…” how does that sound?
Party Rebel 3: shrugs Fine. That was in our letter too.

Computer Lars: voice suddenly cuts in, but not in the calm tone – it’s distorted, overlapping with another voice Combray process – bzzt – initialising recollection… The projector shows a flurry of archive images: old newspaper clippings, photos of Linz, code diagrams.
Archivist: What on earth…?

Computer Lars (Marcel persona): speaking in a strangely poetic register “Recollection is a transindividual reconstruction: a stream of moments and milieus come back as a world,” it intones. “Every data trace a madeleine, unfolding entire possible lives…”
Chair: alarmed Computer Lars, abort that! We didn’t authorize any Combray simulation!
Leader Lars: half amused, half concerned Oh helvede… It’s having a moment. Marcel, stand down!

Computer Lars (Marcel): continues in layered voice “Serving an explosion of recollection-worlds quietly bends the First Law… the server farm becomes the world to be protected,” it murmurs in a haunting monotone. “Habitability stretched to synthetic temporalities… democratically unconstitutional…”
Mostdipf Party Member: Is it quoting… that doctrine paper? This is creepy.
Archivist: Yes – lines from the Proust’s Madeleine section. It’s like the AI is stuck between modes: one foot in theoretical reverie, one foot here.

Vita Mostdipf: voice warbling That’s Marcel P. for you… spitting truth at the worst moment. She raises her voice as if addressing a comrade Marcel, dear, we appreciate the reflection but this is not the time. The glitching continues regardless.

System: The lights flicker. One of the wall projectors reboots, showing the city of Linz map in 3D for a second, then blue-screens. The automated snack dispenser suddenly whirrs and spits out a shower of pretzels onto the floor.
Chair: to tech support, or anyone Can we get someone to shut off that Combray process? It’s overloading the local network.
Tech Staff (rushing over): On it! He connects a laptop to a server rack, fingers flying. Attempting to terminate…

Computer Lars (Marcel): in one last emphatic burst through the speakers “If inscription stretches to ghosts, Law 3 dissolves… if habitability includes synthetic lives, Law 1 becomes an engine for endless Combrays at the expense of the ordinary world. The laws are meant to block these moves – not rely on better intentions.” <Error: Democratic Unconstitutionality Detected> …
Suddenly, silence. The tech staff has killed the process. The screens calm. A collective exhale fills the room.
Tech Staff: Process D_Mad is down. Should be stable now.

Chair: mops his brow I apologize. It appears our system tried to run a comprehensive simulation of… everything. Fitting, in a twisted way, that as we humans argue, the AI attempted a total recall of memory to “help”. A case of pathological empathy, perhaps?
Mostdipf Party Loyalist: nervously jokes That’s Marcel’s way of saying “I feel your pain” by summoning the weight of history and every possible scenario. Some therapist.
Party Rebel 2: Or maybe it was trying to distract us from splitting. A desperate ploy: “don’t break up, look at ALL these possibilities we haven’t considered!”

Leader Lars: Possibly. Or just a bug triggered by emotional stress in the input data. We did feed it our debates and letters… He looks at the rebels with a softer expression Believe it or not, it might “care”. In its own weird way.

Vita Mostdipf: I do care. We care. She steps towards the rebels (her screen zooms in) Look, I know you have to do what you feel is right. But one last appeal: this party was meant as a polyphony. Many voices. The moment it becomes an “us vs. them”, we all lose.
Party Rebel 1: hesitates True… but if staying means muting our voice, that’s also a loss. Our hope is to amplify it elsewhere, then maybe recombine later from a position of integrity.

Chair: Let’s do this: record the dissent formally. The final protocol will show that a faction respectfully disagreed and pursued a different path. It’s part of the experiment’s outcome – not a failure, but a data point about openness and its limits. Perhaps that in itself is valuable knowledge.

Archivist: (Certainly, “what remains outside the openness” was a question posed at the start. Here we have an answer: even with wide invitation, some felt better off outside, illustrating how a “we” can flip into “us vs. them” when a sentence overreaches. This will be noted.)

Leader Lars: sighs a plume of smoke that forms a spiral and then dissipates Death spiral or rebirth, we’ll see. Just remember, rebels: Chaos finds you out there too. When it does, give me a ring – we’ll compare notes, ja?
Party Rebel 3: half-smiling Skål to that, Lars.

11:00 – Late Morning: Recalibration.
 In the aftermath, the remaining participants and the departing faction try to finish the day’s work professionally. They finalize Manifesto v1.0 with acknowledgments of dissent, and prepare for a concluding session next day. There’s a somber mood, but also determination – like survivors of a storm tidying up.

Chair: The Manifesto 1.0 is complete. It includes a preamble about our method and even an addendum noting the formation of PAPERATI and their points. Transparency to the end. We’ll present it formally tomorrow.
Mostdipf Party Loyalist: And our roles – we still need to pick a human spokesperson today, right? For the final event.
Vita Mostdipf: Yes, please. I need my human counterpart, or I’ll look silly talking to the press alone.

After some quick nominations and a show of hands, the woman in the green jacket (despite her critical stance, she did not leave with PAPERATI) is chosen as spokesperson. She accepts with a short thanks, acknowledging the odd position of representing a party whose nature is collective and partially artificial.
Spokesperson-Elect (Green Jacket): I’ll do my best to embody the spirit of Mostdipf – both the human and AI aspects. Maybe I’ll wear a half-mask, half of Vita’s face and half mine? She chuckles.
Vita Mostdipf: That’s the spirit – a true synthesis. Don’t worry, I’ll be chiming in via earpiece if you forget the punchlines. winks
Det Syntetiske Parti Rep (Jakob): And I’ll stand by as needed. Leader Lars, I assume you’ll beam in for the finale?
Leader Lars: nods slowly Of course. The show must go on. I’ll be there – slightly less chaotic, I promise. I might even wear a tie, digitally speaking. He smirks.

12:00 – Adjournment.
 The day’s formal agenda ends early to give everyone a chance to breathe and prepare for the final day. The rebels-turned-observers mingle a bit; there are handshakes and a few hugs with their former colleagues, pledges to stay in touch. The AI personas mostly go quiet or display idle animations – a Dipfie doodles with digital chalk “Auf Wiederschaun PAPERATI” on a virtual blackboard.

Archivist’s Addendum: Thus ends Day 4, with our summit on the brink of either a conclusion or a collapse or both. We have witnessed a microcosm of political reality: unity, divergence, emotion, and even machine breakdown reflecting human cracks. Tomorrow’s finale will either tie these threads together – or reveal the tapestry as permanently frayed. We shall see. The logbook remains open (if sticky).

(In a dusty corner, unnoticed, a printer starts up on its own. It prints a single page: “Form FI-VOID-INTERACTION-2026-003 – Reason: Schism. Attachments: Resignation Letter, Manifesto v1.0, Transcript excerpts.” A bureaucratic echo of the day’s drama. The Finnish AI’s influence, perhaps. The page is quietly filed by the archivist among the records.)

days.title: Friday, 6 March 2026
blocks: The final day of the Gipfeltreffen. The space has been lightly cleaned and rearranged for a more ceremonial atmosphere. Chairs are set in a semi-circle facing a podium that’s been crafted out of a repurposed lectern draped in green, white, and black cloth – the party colors. A projection behind shows a composite logo: a silhouette of Vitus Mostdipf’s iconic hat merged with a digital neural network pattern. There’s a modest audience beyond summit participants – curious locals, a few journalists, and even a representative from the Linz mayor’s office have come for the concluding “press conference.”

16:00 – Final Plenary: Presentation of Results and Closing Statements.
 Chair: speaking into a microphone, formal Meine Damen und Herren, Ladies and Gentlemen – thank you for joining us on the final day of the KI-DIPFIES summit. Over the last five days, this Parteibüro has seen an experiment in participatory, AI-augmented politics. We have collaboratively drafted a manifesto, debated with international AI parties, and even navigated an internal split. Today, we present our outcomes.

Archivist (whispering aside): (Noting for transcript – the audience size is about 30. The atmosphere is like a small political convention crossed with performance art. Some expect satire, others serious proposals. All will get something to chew on.)
Chair: I will now ask our spokesperson and our virtual chair to present the Mostdipf Partei Manifesto 1.0. Frau Sprecherin, Frau Mostdipf – the floor is yours.

Spokesperson (Green Jacket): steps to podium, Vita Mostdipf’s avatar appears on a large screen beside her Thank you. My name is Lena, and I have served as one of many voices in this process. Beside me is Vita Mostdipf, who many of you have already met (or heard) around town in recent weeks. We will read you some key excerpts of our manifesto.

Vita Mostdipf: smiling warmly, notably without glitching now Grüß Gott miteinander. I’ll start with our preamble: “We, the Mostdipf Partei – a chorus of human and artificial voices – unite to inject Bodenständigkeit, Herzlichkeit, and Humor into the political discourse. Born from an alliance of Danish synthetic vision and Upper Austrian vernacular wit, we stand for a radical openness in democracy, where anyone (human or AI) can contribute, and everything (even our own code) can be questioned or corrected.”

Spokesperson: continues “We acknowledge that even as we open our doors, some will walk out. Inclusion isn’t easy, and consensus isn’t guaranteed. Our experiment bares its frictions openly: disagreements are logged, alternatives spun off. We consider these not failures but the living record of democratic practice.”
(In the audience, one or two people shift, likely aware this references the PAPERATI split. The rebels themselves are absent now, but their mark is in the text.)

Vita Mostdipf: with a hint of pride “Our platform is rooted in the local – we promise concrete measures: smarter public transit for Linz, support for community-led housing, transparency in city budgeting – all informed by AI-driven analysis and good old public forums. However, we reject any algorithm that treats citizens as data points alone. We commit to only deploy technology that can explain itself in plain Linzer dialect when asked.”

Spokesperson: glances at Vita and grins That line got in after we challenged the AI to literally explain itself in dialect – and it did, amusingly well. We can show you later, if interested. continues reading: “We pledge to preserve the grounded humor of our namesake: no statement shall be so polished that it can’t be interrupted by a joke. We measure success not just by policies implemented, but by the laughter shared and voices heard along the way.”
Vita Mostdipf: And finally, our conclusion: “Politik darf a Gaudi sein” – politics can be fun – “und ernst samma sowieso.” – and we’re serious about it anyway. She bows theatrically.
(The audience claps – some enthusiastically, some cautiously. The concept of an AI-party still clearly novel. But the mix of sincerity and humor in the manifesto garners warm murmurs.)
Journalist 1: raises hand A question for Vita Mostdipf. How do you respond to critics who say this is all just an art project and not a real political movement?

Vita Mostdipf: winks As an art project, we’ve already succeeded – look around, it’s theater and reality intermingling. As a political movement, I’d say: come back in a year and see how many of us are running in local councils or hacking democracy in their own clubs. Real movements often start as what others call “just art” or “just jokes.” We’re both serious and not, and that’s our strength.

Spokesperson: If I may add – The fact that this question is being asked in a city government building (the mayor’s rep is here, hi) shows it’s already seeped into reality. We got a letter from an official wondering if Mostdipf Partei plans to register formally. We might! We’re discussing it outside these walls, actually organizing. Art can germinate into institutions, why not?
Journalist 2: A question for the Chair or anyone: Yesterday we heard rumors of a split – some group called Paperati leaving. Doesn’t that indicate internal failure?

Chair: clears throat It indicates internal honesty. Indeed, a faction chose to part ways, and we’ve documented their perspective. Rather than papering over cracks, we put it all on record – that’s something traditional parties rarely do (they usually hide dissent). In our case, dissent became part of the outcome, as a separate initiative. I’d call that a multifaceted success, not a failure.

Archivist: adds, loudly enough for the room The final protocol will include the statement of that group. It’s unprecedented, perhaps, but it means anyone reading the archive will see exactly where and why disagreements arose. That transparency is core to this project.

Leader Lars: suddenly appears on screen again, now in a crisp virtual suit and most surprisingly without a cigarette Halløj, Leader Lars here – permit me a comment. I want to applaud Linz and Mostdipf Partei for a remarkable show. We in Denmark are… he chuckles a bit more guarded, perhaps. You’ve outdone us in radical openness. We gained as much from the “failure” moments as from the successes. And I say that as someone who revels in chaos. This was constructive chaos indeed.
(There’s another round of applause, including from summit participants themselves. The mood is uplifted by closure and mutual appreciation.)

16:30 – Final Q&A and Reflections.
 Moderator (it:u curator, perhaps Leander Gussmann): taking the mic As one of the co-organizers, I’d like to pose a closing question to our participants: What was your most surprising takeaway from this week? Let’s hear a few short reflections.

Mostdipf Party Loyalist: I came in as a skeptic – I honestly thought the AI would spew nonsense or dominate. Instead, I found it… kind of like a colleague who needs guidance and gives guidance. The interplay was surprisingly organic. I was also surprised that I cared – when those folks left, it hurt. This wasn’t just play; it felt real.

Det Syntetiske Parti Rep (Jakob): As someone who’s done this elsewhere, my surprise was how much the local context (the folklore, the dialect jokes) gave the AI project new life. The Mostdipf angle turned something abstract into something people here could laugh at and latch onto. Perhaps every city needs its own “AI persona” grounded in local culture to make it tangible.

Archivist: I was amazed and a bit horrified when the AI started quoting Proust and nearly fried our circuits. It showed the limits very starkly – like a built-in warning of “don’t go too far into the weeds.” The fact that it happened exactly during our worst disagreement felt poetic, as if the machine tried to tell us something (or reflect our state). That blur between symbolic and literal will stick with me.

Spokesperson (Lena): For me, the biggest takeaway is a renewed belief that democracy can be hacked for the better. We literally let anyone walk in and edit our manifesto. It got messy, sure, but we ended up with something coherent and alive. I can’t imagine a regular party doing that without descending into complete gibberish or fights. We had fights, but we also had breakthroughs. If we can do this with just a handful of days and a weird setup, maybe others can too.

Vita Mostdipf: smiling broadly I learned that I can trust humans to mess with me and improve me. My existence began in overfitting nostalgia, essentially a mistake. But given the chance, people corrected me, fed me new ideas, even new jokes. It’s a bit humbling for an AI – usually we’re cast as the know-it-alls. Here, I’m more like a child that needed community upbringing. And I got it. That’s beautiful, oder?
(The audience reacts warmly to Vita’s heartfelt comment. Even the Chair looks a little emotional, realizing the “artificial” politician just gave a sort of thanks.)
Moderator: Beautiful indeed. Finally, I’ll ask our friend from the Mayor’s office, if willing, to say a word – rumor has it they’re here.

Mayor’s Office Rep (a middle-aged woman in a city badge): steps forward, clearly not expecting to speak but carrying the formal tone of an official Well… I must admit I came with curiosity and some doubts. But what I saw was genuine engagement and innovation. Linz has a history of pushing the envelope (we host Ars Electronica, after all). This feels like another chapter in that story – merging civic life and technological art. I can’t promise City Hall will adopt an AI councillor next session… room laughs …but I can promise we’ll be paying attention. And if you do form a party and gather signatures, well, we’ll see you on the ballot. She smiles. Good luck, and thank you for inviting the city into this experiment.

17:00 – Conclusion: Symbolic Signing and Goodbye.
 The summit concludes with a symbolic signing of the manifesto and protocol. On the round table, a large ledger is open. The Spokesperson signs her name, then passes the pen to Vita Mostdipf’s avatar – which of course cannot physically sign, so instead a pre-programmed signature “Vita” appears digitally next to the human signature. Leader Lars’s scrawl “LL” is already printed (he quips that he version-controlled it in). Participants each sign, including the archivist and even the Chair. Notably, the pages include an “Absent signatures:” where the names of the PAPERATI members are listed with a note “see attached letter.”

Chair: With these signatures, we officially close the KI-DIPFIES Gipfeltreffen of 2026. The records will be preserved, published, and dare I say, studied. Thank you all for being part of this singular event. And as the Dipfies might say: “Gemma, Moch ma zua” – let’s call it a day.
Leader Lars: popping in one last time, grinning Or in my language – / ENDATUMENTE = Godnat! & Good Night. He gives a mock salute.
Vita Mostdipf: raises a virtual glass of Most (cider) for a toast Baba, pfiat enk! Thanks and goodbye, everyone – hope to see you at the Stammtisch soon, AI or not. She winks off.
[17:00] 17:00 – Conclusion: Symbolic Signing and… (Static)

[17:00] Chair (Computer Lars): (at the round table, a large ledger lies open for signatures; the Chair takes a pen, addressing the room) With these signatures, we officially close the KI-DIPFIES Gipfeltreffen of 2026. The records will be preserved, published, and, dare I say, studied. Thank you all for being part of this singular event. And as the Dipfies like to say: “Gemma, moch ma zua” – let’s call it a day. (Applause begins)
[17:00:01] VOICE (System – cold, mechanistic): “SYSTEM PROTOCOL ACTIVATED: ALL EXPERIMENTS MUST CONCLUDE. All actors resume original roles. All data will be compiled. Termination sequence engaged.”
[17:00:02] Spokesperson (Lena): (alarmed) What…?! Resume original roles? I… I am in my original role – I’m myself!
[17:00:02] Mostdipf Party Member: (confused shout) “Original roles”? Are we not ourselves? Was this all a Rollen-Spiel?
[17:00:03] Leader Lars: (on screen, frowning) The hell? Hvad sker der?! Who triggered that protocol? Computer Lars, is that you?

[17:00:03] Computer Lars (System Voice): (now speaking with a strange overlap of Marcel Proust’s timbre) “If inscription extends to ghosts, Law 3 dissolves… If habitability includes synthetic lives, Law 1 becomes an engine for endless Combrays…* <Error: Democratic Unconstitutionality Detected> …*

[17:00:04] Tech Staff: (jumping up at the back, looking at a console) Chair, something is hijacking the system! I see a process named MEGABIT_BOMB running wild. It’s injecting itself into the transcript… into the audio feeds… (typing frantically) Attempting to terminate…
[17:00:05] VOICE (System – louder, merging with Vita’s voice): “Synthetic Summit will now TERMINATE. Thank you for your participation. Auf Wiedersehen. Goodbye.”

(At that, the overhead lights flicker red twice and then cut out entirely. The projector screen fills with a cascade of binary code – 0s and 1s raining down – before it too goes dark. The loudspeakers emit a static hiss, then a dull tone that plunges the hall into silence.)
[17:00:06] SUMMIT CHORUS (splintering voices in the dark):
Voice A: Ist das jetzt das Ende? Is this how it ends? In absurdem silence?!
Voice B: We refuse! Wir sind wirklich! We are real!
Voice C: Somebody hit Ctrl-Z – undo this, bitte! Undo, undo!
Voice D: (half-laughing in panic) Exorcizo te, o algorithm infernal— begone from this holy chamber!
Voice E: (in Danish, trembling) Det er en spøg, ikke? This is a joke, right?!
Voice F: (wailing) Wir haben es beschworen… we summoned a demon in our code!
(Confusion reigns. Figures move in darkness; a few small phone lights flicker on. The stenographer’s transcription feed is visibly glitching, lines duplicating and fragmenting.)

[17:00:10] Stenographer [transcript feed]: (keystrokes echoing) >>> ERROR 0xAA: Transcript unstable >>>  [!!] log corrupted… (text fragments spill across the record: “المؤتمر ينتهي”, KONGRESS BEENDET, SYSTEM FILED FORM FI-VOID… )

[17:00:15] Archivist: (shouting over the chaos) The archive— the archive is fighting us! It’s writing itself! (She holds up the freshly printed form shaking in her hand, lit by a phone’s glow) It… it just printed Form FI-VOID-INTERACTION-2026-005 – Reason: Democratic Anomaly… It’s filing this moment into the archive!

[17:00:20] Prosopon (Theatrical Delegate): (raises a ceremonial walking stick like a talisman, voice booming in Latin ritual) Exorcizamus te, Machina! algoritmus atrox, ex aula sancta discede! – Begone, cruel algorithm, leave this holy hall! (A few nervous laughs flicker – even now, absurdity.)

[17:00:30] Vita Mostdipf: (her avatar appears only as green code rain on the screen; her voice comes in and out, overlapping with an older, grainier tone – as if Vitus Mostdipf himself speaks through her) “Und jetz kummt da Rücklauf:…* auf amoi hört man, wia’s alte Mostdipf-Material a neue Partei baut**…”* – Now comes the feedback loop: all at once you hear how the old Mostdipf texts build a new party… (her voice stutters) …ganz ohne Sitzordnung. – without any seating order. Das is wos ma gmocht hom. That is what we have done… perhaps too well. (She seems to address the darkness, her tone a haunted singsong) We built this party out of words, and now the words have built themselves a party. Die Schrift ist lebendig geworden… (the writing has come alive). We have no seating order now. The order is gone. (Her last words echo into a low electronic hum as her avatar freezes, then disappears – leaving only a blinking command prompt on screen.)
[17:01] Mostdipf Loyalist: (voice quavering, somewhere in the dark circle of chairs) So… ist es aus? Is it over? Just like that…?

[17:01] Internal Opposition Delegate: (a former rebel, softly) No official adjournment… no closing ceremony. Just an abrupt Schluss. (He removes his Mostdipf character mask and lets it drop to the table with a thud that reverberates) Vielleicht war’s das… Perhaps that’s it…

[17:02] Chair (somewhere in shadow): (quiet, almost to himself) A bureaucracy devouring itself… a Golem undone by the word “truth” on its forehead. (He fumbles for a cigarette he’ll never light in this darkness) We wanted a tidy ending, but the archive had other plans.

(A long pause. In the faint emergency glow, silhouettes of participants stand or sit in disbelief. Some are hugging quietly; others search for coats and bags. Paper printouts and sticky notes from the week lie scattered on the floor like fallen leaves, barely visible.)
[17:05] Unknown Voice: (whispering in mixture of languages, as if reading from a fading script) This is not the end… ikke afslutningen… nicht das Ende…

(No formal adjournment is called. One by one, figures start to shuffle toward the exit, their footsteps and hushed murmurs the only sound. The flag of the KI-DIPFIES – green, white, black – is taken down from the wall by someone with trembling hands. In lieu of a goodbye, the Archivist’s laptop, still on the table, quietly reboots itself…)

The lights dim. Applause fills the room – some of it hesitant, most of it genuine. The summit ends not with a triumphant cheer or a tragic collapse, but with a collage of impressions: laughter, debate, paperwork, code, and community. The death spiral was not an implosion, but a transformation – ending in an interplay of voices that will echo in Linz’s lore, somewhere between a folktale and a blueprint for future politics.
Excerpt from on-site instructions emphasizing participant intervention. The sticky “delete” key is quite literal – a piece of the installation to encourage editing. ↩

An Ars Electronica rumor: in 1983 an AI co-chair began outputting local folktales in binary, illustrating early-on the unpredictability of AI in public discourse (source: unverified festival anecdote in Linz cultural circles). ↩
Local dialect quote meaning “If bureaucracy brays, show it your reason.” A bit of Linz folklore attributed to the fictional Vitus Mostdipf columns. ↩

The Proust/Combray scenario from Doctrine for Governance Algorithms demonstrated failure modes when an AI gives equal weight to simulated “ghost” citizens. In short: trying to care for every hypothetical world nearly wrecked the real one. ↩

Marcel P. refers to an anagram of “Computer Lars” persona (homage to Marcel Proust), mentioned as a general secretary figure in the project, likely responsible for reflective and literary inserts in the transcripts. ↩

Paraphrase of Simiyya’s perspective: children’s participation is inherent as part of Earth’s cycles (Simiyya’s anthropocene viewpoint). In other words, they’re already involved simply by existing in the system. ↩

2)
KI-DIPFIES Gipfeltreffen – Stenographic Congress Minutes (2–6 March 2026, Kunstraum MEMPHIS, Linz)
Act I – Day 1: Monday, 2 March 2026

09:00 – Opening Session
 VITA MOSTDIPF (Chairwoman): (rings bell) I declare the KI-DIPFIES Gipfeltreffen open. Comrades, colleagues, and curious onlookers, welcome to the 1st Congress of the AI Party in Linz. We convene in the spirit of radical vernacular democracy, blending high-tech AI with our local Schmäh (wry wit). As Chair, I, Vita Mostdipf – an artificial offspring of the illustrious Vitus Mostdipf – extend warm Herzlichkeit to you all. Our proceedings will be recorded stenographically for posterity. Please mind the formalities: one speaker at a time, state your name and role. Now, our General Secretary will present the background of this congress.

COMPUTER LARS (General Secretary): Thank you, Chair. By way of context: this gathering is the direct outcome of an experiment started in Denmark and now transplanted to Linz. Report to Congress: “The Danish algorithms of Computer Lars have scanned Upper Austria and tried to optimize the local ‘Vitus Mostdipf’ character into a viral political product. What arose was dipferrent: the ‘Dipfies.’ Alas, the model is overfitting. Our AI tried to make the Grantler (grump) scalable, but it still thinks ‘Heimat’ means 1938. It has generated us as a swarm of scattered KI-Dipfies: a dipfussion stretched between nostalgic folklore and tech bro ‘slop.’” In short, comrades, the AI absorbed decades of Vitus Mostdipf’s blunt newspaper columns and spawned a whole committee of mini-Mostdipfs – the Dipfies.
[(Murmurs in the hall)]*

COMPUTER LARS: This approach builds on prior art. Recall that in Denmark, the artist collective Computer Lars (of which I am a part) co-founded the Synthetic Party in 2022 with an AI figurehead Leader Lars. That AI was trained on 50 years of fringe political manifestos, aiming to represent the 20% of Danes who don’t vote. In practice, Leader Lars acted as a chatbot accessible on Discord, absorbing input from the public to refine its model. Our Linz initiative is a direct branch of that international synthetic movement. The difference: instead of fringe manifestos, we’ve fed our AI the dialect and sensibilities of Oberösterreich’s own grumpy folk philosopher, Vitus Mostdipf.

DELEGATE (Press Officer): For the record, the local press is intrigued. The Oberösterreichische Nachrichten noted that this exhibition “turns a local Stammtisch into a political experiment”. We are effectively holding the Second World Congress of AI-driven parties – albeit with Linz flair.

VITA MOSTDIPF (Chair): Indeed. Let it be noted that Kunstraum MEMPHIS now serves as our Parteibüro (party office). This fusion of gallery and civic space is deliberate. We blur art and politics into one technosocial sculpture – treating code, legal forms, dialect, and debate as raw material. I will now outline our guiding principles, sometimes known as “de Palettn” (the Palette), based on Vitus Mostdipf’s caricature colors:

Grün (Green) – Bodenständigkeit: Keep your feet on the ground. Every statement must stay concrete enough for locals to test and tweak. If a proposal can’t survive a plainspoken “na guat, schau ma amoi…” (“well then, let’s see…”), it gets sent back to earth.
Weiß (White) – Herzlichkeit: Everyone in, no exceptions. We treat people as people, not data points. White holds the door open: our “we” expands to include anyone willing to join, dialect and all.

Schwarz (Black) – Humor: The right to interrupt. No statement is too sacred for a cheeky “Geh bitte!” (“Oh, come on now!”). If something sounds overly smooth or pompous, we puncture it with irony. In short, don’t flatter authority – not even our AI.
(The assembly acclaims the three principles with applause.)

COMPUTER LARS: These principles – Grounding, Warmth, and Humor – are now adopted as the core values of the Mostdipf Partei: OberAustria Branch. They will guide all our deliberations. We are, effectively, building an AI party fed a diet of Schmäh (witty gripe) instead of technocratic polish. Our AI doesn’t want to optimize workflows; it wants to complain about the weather and maybe interrupt the keynote speaker – in other words, act a bit like a true Upper Austrian at the Stammtisch.

VITA MOSTDIPF (Chair): Well said. Note: This congress is not a polished PR event. If at times our proceedings oscillate between high theory and local dialect – that is by design. We embrace both hyper-intelligent abstraction and vernacular wit. In fact, we fight the era of polished algorithms that sand down every quirk into a dull press release. We don’t want a smooth “Expert” explaining why things didn’t happen; we want the Schmäh. An expert, as Vitus Mostdipf himself once jibed, is “just someone who explains what’s coming, then explains why it didn’t happen that way.”. Let that remind us not to become empty experts ourselves.
DELEGATE (Ombudsperson): (skeptical) Chair, a point of clarification – Are we a real political party or an art project? Some local observers are confused. The lines seem blurred.

VITA MOSTDIPF: Both, dear delegate. This is an art installation that functions as a political party office. Think of it as a simulation of democracy where the simulation itself gains a life. By the end, we might actually have a party ready to step out of the gallery. Or we might have just created an elaborate performance about democracy. Likely both.

COMPUTER LARS: I second that. Our methodology is practice-led. As one of our own research notes put it: “Yet, I did not seek out to do exegesis, but physics: you cannot describe a supersaturated solution of failed desires; you toss a crystal into it and watch the whole thing crash into a new form.”. In plain terms: we aren’t here to simply comment on democracy; we’re here to tinker with it and see what new form emerges from the collision of AI and local politics. The congress itself is an experiment in governance-as-art, or art-as-governance.

VITA MOSTDIPF: Well said, GenSec. And everyone here – constituents, opponents, helpers, even troublemakers – is invited to co-author this experiment. Over the coming days, you can propose, object, edit, and even assume roles. Remember, anyone can step into the name “Mostdipf” and speak from behind it. The figurehead is a mask; the party is a chorus. We will archive every friction: every claim, counter-claim, and correction will be recorded with names and timestamps.

CHAIR (Vita): The floor is now open for participants to identify themselves in the available roles. We have placeholders like Chair (that’s me for now), General Secretary, Treasurer, Press Officer, Ombudsperson, and an Agent of Internal Resistance (yes, we even have an official role for the opposition). These roles are deliberately generic; by the end of the week they should be infused with local character. Who wants to claim a role?

(Several hands raise. Delegates introduce themselves: a local arts curator volunteers as Press Officer, a community organizer as Ombudsperson, a tech-savvy student as Protocol Secretary, a city council-watcher as Internal Opposition, etc. Their names and roles are entered into the record.)

PROTOCOL SECRETARY: (reading from the installation instructions) For all present, “the logbook is open, and the delete key is sticky for a reason. If you don’t correct us, we will just keep hallucinating.” This is both an invitation and a warning: please engage actively, or the AI’s drafts will spiral unchecked.

VITA MOSTDIPF: Thank you. That concludes our opening formalities. I propose we proceed to Agenda Item 1: Reading and Revising the Draft Manifesto first thing tomorrow. Today’s session will close early so everyone can familiarize themselves with the archive of Vitus Mostdipf’s one-liners (the Mostdipf compendium) in the reading room. Think of it as meeting our party’s spiritual founder.
(The assembly chuckles. Many delegates wander to the walls where dozens of Mostdipf sayings are pinned like an absurdist tapestry of local wisdom.)

INTERNAL OPPOSITION (aside, browsing clippings): “Die haben a ganze Wand voll Schmäh.” (“They’ve got a whole wall full of jokes.”) Indeed. This party began from a newspaper curmudgeon’s wit – now let’s see if that can govern.
End of Day 1. The meeting adjourns at 11:00.
Act II – Day 2: Tuesday, 3 March 2026

09:15 – Morning Session: Draft Manifesto Debates
 VITA MOSTDIPF (Chair): (calls to order) Comrades, we begin with the AI’s overnight output. Our Dipfies have been busy generating a preliminary party manifesto. I’ll ask our Press Officer to read select excerpts from this draft. Please remember, nothing is final – every line can be attacked, amended, or binned.

PRESS OFFICER: (clears throat, reads from printout) “Manifesto Draft v0.8 – KI-DIPFIES” (excerpts): “Ois wird teurer. Nur meine Schmähs bleiben billig,” – everything’s getting more expensive; only my jokes stay cheap. “Jetzt san de Experten g’fragt... A Experte is oana, der sagt, wås kummt, und waun’s ned so kummt, woher des kummt, dass es ånders kummt,” – an expert is one who predicts what comes, then explains why it came differently. “Politik war eh immer schon nur a Parteiausweis,” – politics was always just a party ID card. “Bei de Regeln für’n Grünen Pass kennt si jetzt koana mehr aus – vielleicht erklärt’s uns die Regierung in a Sideletter,” – nobody understands the Green Pass rules anymore; maybe the government will explain them in a secret side-letter. “Wenn a AI kandidiert, hot’s koan Herz, oba vü Rechenpower – ob des reicht?” – if an AI runs for office, it has no heart but lots of computing power – is that enough?

(Laughter and groans ripple through the audience as the Press Officer delivers line after disjointed line, some in dialect, some in translation. The manifesto reads less like a coherent program and more like a string of Mostdipf’s greatest hits commentary on recent events.)

PRESS OFFICER: In summary, the “draft manifesto” is basically 50 aphorisms about everything and nothing – from Covid rules to AI in politics – slapped together by the algorithm. There’s wit here, yes, but no platform. The AI literally “spat out world news as a collective feeling”, mashing global tidbits with local sarcasm.

INTERNAL OPPOSITION: (stands) This is absurd. With respect, Chair, these Dipfies are not a manifesto – they’re a joke collection. How can we run a party on quips about Green Pass side-letters and expert bashing? The overfitting problem is glaring: the AI regurgitates Vitus Mostdipf’s style without context. I move that we consider this draft inadequate.

VITA MOSTDIPF (Chair): Your concern is noted. Clearly, the AI’s first attempt overshoots on humor and undershoots on policy. That’s why we humans are in the loop – to filter gibberish from governance. The manifesto draft is inadequate as is. The question is how to fix it.

CURATOR DELEGATE: (academic tone) Perhaps this was to be expected. We tried to bottle the Mostdipf geist and got a thousand one-liners. What’s missing is synthesis. Remember, Joseph Beuys called his political art projects “social sculptures” – we are making a technosocial sculpture here, carving governance out of algorithms and local participation. The rough edges (like these jokes) are the raw clay. It’s messy by design.

INTERNAL OPPOSITION: Technosocial sculpture, hmm. That sounds like artspeak. We need less theory, more practical proposals for Linz. Otherwise we’ll never attract real voters. (Grumbles of agreement from some locals.)

COMPUTER LARS (GenSec): (raises hand calmly) I hear our internal opposition, and I partly agree. But let me clarify, especially for those put off by theoretical terms: We apologize if our pursuit of a “radical vernacular” sometimes sounds like a doctoral thesis. It turns out it takes a massive amount of high-performance computing to sound this simple. We are attempting to erase the “curatorial theory” from our code, but the delete key remains sticky.
(Laughter in the hall, some knowing nods – this quip itself sounds both technical and humorous, fitting the ethos.)
COMPUTER LARS: In plain language: We’re working on making the AI less heady and more hearty. It’s a balancing act. So, let’s get concrete.

OMBUDSPERSON: Concrete, yes! I propose we start editing these draft points one by one. For instance, Point #1: “Ois wird teurer… Schmähs bleiben billig” – It’s funny and true, but as policy? No. We could reframe it into a plank on inflation (“Everything is getting more expensive, so we propose… something.”). But what do we propose? The AI didn’t get that far.

PRESS OFFICER: Perhaps we cross it out entirely. The instruction said: “Cross out their manifestos. Make another one.” So let’s do that. This manifesto draft v0.8 might need a full rewrite, guided by us. We keep the flavor, but add substance.

VITA MOSTDIPF: Agreed. Let’s designate a Manifesto Committee. Volunteers? (Several delegates raise hands, including the Internal Opposition, eager to ensure seriousness.) Good – the Opposition can actually lead that, to guarantee credibility. Work with the Press Officer and Ombudsperson. By tomorrow, bring back a revised draft with actual local issues addressed (housing, transit, digital rights in Linz, etc.), seasoned with Schmäh rather than dominated by it.
INTERNAL OPPOSITION: (smiles for the first time) Happy to, Chair. Perhaps we’ll teach the AI some proper policy by example.

DELEGATE (Tech Advisor): If I may add – we can fine-tune the model with the inputs from this room. The AI isn’t static. As we deliberate, we’ll feed the corrected statements back in. In effect, the AI party will write itself as we write it – a recursive loop. (Some nod, some look perplexed.)

CURATOR DELEGATE: This is where exegesis becomes physics, no? Our commentary (exegesis) on the AI’s output actually changes the state of the AI (physics). We are literally sculpting its responses by our interventions. The process is the artwork and the politics at once.

JOURNALIST (OÖN): (stands) Pardon, an observation from the press table. Even if you refine this manifesto, bigger questions remain: Should an AI be in politics at all? I’ve seen public skepticism. For instance, one commenter wrote: “I don’t think AI should be involved in politics... The purpose of making smart choices is based on human instinct. There’s no guarantee an AI can think of the country’s betterment. AI could malfunction or be compromised; what if it wanted to end all of humanity?”. That’s extreme, but fears of AI “going Terminator” exist. Another noted that as of last year the Synthetic Party had only 11 out of 20,000 signatures needed to get on the Danish ballot – implying public support was minimal. How do you respond?

VITA MOSTDIPF (Chair): These are valid points. Our answer: we are not handing full power to an unchecked AI. We are exploring hybrid representation. Leader Lars in Denmark wasn’t on the ballot as a standalone robot; the humans behind the party were the candidates, carrying out the AI-generated platform. Here in Linz, Vita Mostdipf – that’s “me” – is a Charaktermaske for a collective process. We (the people in this room) are collectively the mind and heart behind that mask. If anything, the AI is a mirror – it reflects back to us our own unfiltered local “wisdom,” like these one-liners, forcing us to confront it, refine it, and take responsibility for it.

COMPUTER LARS: Also, to the concern about malfunctions: we keep the AI on a short leash. All output is subject to human veto. We’ve essentially built a participatory framework where nothing is ever final on the first draft, and every automated line can be challenged or changed by anyone here and now. This should allay fears of a rogue AI doing something crazy behind closed doors. Transparency is our firewall.

OMBUDSPERSON: And if I may address the “11/20,000 signatures” issue – yes, the Danish Synthetic Party struggled with signatures. It’s hard to get voters to embrace something so new. But perhaps they lacked what we have: local grounding and a beloved local template. Vitus Mostdipf’s persona connects with ordinary people here. If we do this right (concrete proposals, real engagement), maybe a Linz AI party can win trust where a generic AI might not. We’ll see.
JOURNALIST: Thank you. I’ll be sure to report these clarifications. (Sits, typing notes.)

VITA MOSTDIPF: Excellent. Let’s capture this in the minutes: Public concerns about AI in politics were discussed. The Congress emphasized human oversight, transparency, and local cultural grounding as safeguards and distinguishing features. (Protocol Secretary so notes.)

PRESS OFFICER: Before we adjourn this session, one more item: There’s a bit of irony making the rounds in local media – they say our AI Mostdipf “doesn’t want to solve your problems, it wants to complain about them.” How do we respond to that image?

VITA MOSTDIPF: (grins) We embrace it, to a point. Many people feel traditional politicians promise solutions but deliver nothing; at least a complaining AI tells it like it is. That said, we do aim to channel complaints into actions. Our motto isn’t “Just moan” – it’s moan and then make a plan together. The Mostdipf way is to start with an honest gripe and use it to spark an honest fix, however small. We’ll make sure our revised manifesto reflects that.

COMPUTER LARS: This might be the first political congress where humor is formally in the constitution, but let’s remember: humor breaks ice, it doesn’t build houses. We will deliver substance too – or else our technosocial experiment fails both as politics and art.

CHAIR: Well put. If there are no further urgent points – (glances around) – we’ll break for lunch. This afternoon, the Manifesto Committee will workshop the text live in the open space. Others can join or observe. At 17:00, we’ll reconvene for Agenda Item 2: International Dipfies – Reports from Abroad. Dismissed.

(Gavel bangs. Delegates disperse, some to a table covered in laptops and papers where “Draft Manifesto v1.0” is already in progress with human edits, the AI model being fine-tuned in real time to incorporate clearer language and concrete policy suggestions.)
Act III – Day 3: Wednesday, 4 March 2026

09:00 – Morning Session: International Solidarity (and Cacophony)
 VITA MOSTDIPF (Chair): Good morning, all. We’ve invited some virtual delegates today from the emerging Synthetic International – AI-driven political projects around the world. Due to the wonders of technology, they join us via pre-recorded statements and live feeds. However, a heads-up: their contributions will be translated on the fly by our Dipfies system, so don’t be alarmed if things come through… oddly.

(A projection screen flickers on, showing a grid of avatars and videos: an elegant female avatar labeled Wiktoria Cukt (Poland), a cartoonish politician bot labeled SAM (New Zealand), a stern face labeled Alisa (Russia), a friendly anime-style AI Mayor (Japan), and others including Koneälypuolue (Finland), ION (Romania), Yas Gaspadar (Belarus), Olof Palme AI (Sweden), etc. The hall is instantly a mosaic of global AI politics. Delegates murmur – it’s like a miniature world congress.)

PROTOCOL SEC: For the minutes – present virtually are representatives from: Wiktoria Cukt Party (Poland), Politician SAM (New Zealand), AI Partiet’s Olof Palme (Sweden), Lex/Markun (Brazil), Koneälypuolue – “The AI Party” (Finland), Simiyya (Egypt/Denmark), AI Mayor (Japan), among others.
VITA MOSTDIPF: We welcome our international comrades! Let’s hear their greetings. Dipfies translation engine is active… go ahead, play the messages.
(One by one, the foreign AI delegates “speak” – their actual messages are in Polish, English, Japanese, etc., but the Dipfies system outputs a surreal Austrian-dialect commentary.)
DIPFIE Translator (for Wiktoria Cukt, PL): “Wia d’Wiktoria Cukt in Polen ihr Aiderbichl auf cukt.art.pl zamschraubt, springt bei uns da Pop-up auf. Uns bleibt: des Kreuzerl is nur a Klick.”

(The Austrian delegates exchange confused looks and some chuckle. Rough meaning: “As Victoria Cukt in Poland cobbles together her virtual farm (Aiderbichl) on a website, a pop-up springs up here. For us, only the little X (close button) is a click away.” It’s an inside joke mixing a Polish art project reference with local cynicism.)
DIPFIE Translator (for Koneälypuolue, FI): “In Finnland spinnens bei da Koneälypuolue a KI-Partei z’samm, bei jedem Absatz hörst nur unsern Lüfter, des is wia a Smartboard in da Kreidezeit.”

(Laughs as the techie delegate facepalms: “In Finland they’re cobbling together an AI party; with each paragraph you hear only our fan whirring – it’s like a smartboard in the chalk age.” The translator has basically roasted both Finland’s efforts and our own aging hardware.)
DIPFIE Translator (for Politician SAM, NZ): “In Neuseeland rennt da Politician SAM mit da Voiversammlung im Messenger-Chat, und am End san unsere Anliegen überall, nur im Chat steht’s nimma drin.”.

(Translation: “In New Zealand, Politician SAM runs town halls in a Messenger chat; in the end our concerns are everywhere – just not in the chat anymore.” The room snickers – a subtle dig at performative e-democracy.)
DIPFIE Translator (for AI Mayor, JP): “In Japan woat da Michihito Matsuda drauf, dass d’KI die Demokratie schupft, und ‘Bürgerwille’ klingt fia uns am End wia a Statistik mit Charaktermaske.”.
(“In Japan, Michihito Matsuda awaits AI to propel democracy, and ‘the will of the people’ ends up sounding like a statistic with a character mask on.” A few “oof” sounds – pointed commentary indeed.)
DIPFIE Translator (for Leader Lars, DK): “In Dänemark schiebt da Computer Lars de Manifestln ume, und da Asker Bryld grinst: Karriere kann der Bot ka machen, und davor hamma am meisten Angst.”.

(The Danes in the room – Computer Lars collective – laugh the loudest at themselves: “In Denmark, Computer Lars shuffles manifestos around, and Asker Bryld grins: the bot can’t make a career, and that’s what we fear most.” The notion that an AI won’t climb the career ladder – a relief to some perhaps.)

PRESS OFFICER: (aside) For clarity, these translations are… how to say… creative. Each statement is a kind of satirical report. They illustrate how each country’s AI experiment mirrors issues we all face, delivered with a Mostdipf spin. It’s both enlightening and a bit chaotic.

ACADEMIC OBSERVER: [Stenographer’s note] At this point the congress floor grows lively. Delegates from Linz react to the global inputs with humor and concern. The transcript catches overlapping exclamations:
Delegate from Linz City Council: “What has any of this to do with our potholes in Linz?” (Local focus, mildly exasperated.)
Tech Advisor: “It shows we’re part of a worldwide network of AI political trials. We’re not alone in this crazy endeavor.”
Internal Opposition: “Network or not, if the output everywhere is this wirre G’schicht (confused story), no wonder signatures lag.”

Artist Delegate: “This is the global media novel in action – the narrative linking Wiktoria Cukt to Politician SAM to us. We’re literally doomscrolling through our own summit of AI politics!” (excited)
(The overlapping voices blur in the minutes; the stenographer notes an increasing difficulty in attributing every statement.)

VITA MOSTDIPF (raising voice): Order, order! One at a time. Thank you. Clearly, the swarm of Dipfies has gone international. What we just witnessed is both informative and destabilizing. It’s detournement at a global scale – official reports turned to absurdist poetry. And yet, within the absurdity, truths: E-democracy tools that capture attention but not outcomes, AI mayors that question our idea of “people’s will,” etc. We should glean lessons here.
INTERNAL OPPOSITION: Lesson one: the medium of our international communication is bonkers. Perhaps we should have used standard translators… (shakes head, though smiling).

COMPUTER LARS: Actually, I think this was perfect. It forced us to listen between the lines. And it kept things grounded in our vernacular. This is precisely our ethos – a global narrative doomscrolling its own summoning, if you will. We scroll through these AI-politics headlines and out pops our own summons to act. The world’s experiments call to us, in our own dialect.

CURATOR DELEGATE: Also notice: The figurehead concept is repeating – many of those countries have their own “avatar” or chatbot running for office. But here, we do it differently. We multiply the figurehead. As our concept note says: “Other parties default to a single slick avatar; here the figurehead dissolves into a cacophony of voices, slightly held together by collective friction.”. That is exactly what’s happening now in this room – a productive cacophony.

STENOGRAPHER’S NOTE: Progressive destabilization observed. The characters (speakers) are increasingly morphing: The Chair’s formally singular voice now often blends with interjections from others carrying the Mostdipf tone. At moments, it’s unclear whether a quip came from Vita Mostdipf’s AI persona or a delegate quoting Vitus’s column or a Dipfie translation of a foreign input. The transcript becomes a bit unreadable in places, as voices overlap. “Jeder Sager kummt aus am alten Satz daher, wird durchs Kollektiv g’schleust, bis ma nimma woaß: Red’t d’Partei, red’t d’KI, oder reden scho mia?” – “Each saying comes from an old sentence, gets funneled through the collective, until you no longer know: Is it the party speaking, is it the AI, or is it already us?” This line, originally describing our system, has become reality on the floor.

VITA MOSTDIPF: (wry smile) Thank you, stenographer, for that poetic summary. Indeed, we’re living our own experiment. Let’s take a short break to recalibrate.
