We’ve run a tight ship, but also a playful one. In true post-farce fashion, maybe the summit itself has one more joke to play.
(Some look around curiously. A few lights flicker – perhaps coincidentally.)
[11:17] (Suddenly, the lights in the room dim and the projector screen that has been displaying the live transcription starts flashing with an old newspaper image.)
[11:17] Vita Mostdipf (AI, with an unusual tone): (in an older, crackling voice than before) “Heit versprich i hoch und heilig: Meine Schmäh san ålle von mir...”
(Gasps. That is Vitus Mostdipf’s voice – the original, recognizable from radio clips – seemingly coming through Vita.)
Vita/Vitus voice (continuing): “…und net vo irgendan KI-Dipf!” (“...and not from some AI dipf!”).
(There is stunned silence, then a burst of laughter and clapping. Some delegates jump to their feet in amazement.)
[11:18] Press Officer (astonished): For the record – our AI chair just channeled Vitus Mostdipf’s own catchphrase, denying AI influence – as our final send-off!

[11:18] Robo-Soph: The audacity! The AI literally gave the last word to the curmudgeon’s ghost, who basically said: “All my jokes are mine, not some AI’s”. In other words, the very thing we worked to disprove.

[11:19] Computer Lars: Or perhaps to prove in a roundabout way. Think about it – we (the humans) wrote all these jokes for the AI. So in truth, none of the Schmähs were actually the AI’s invention – they were ours. Vitus’s spirit can indeed claim the jokes are human, not machine. It’s a perfect loop.
(The attendees murmur in agreement, some in awe of the poetic perfection: the project ends with Vitus Mostdipf’s persona asserting its dominance one last time, tongue-in-cheek.)
[11:20] Magda (smiling, shaking her head): Straight-faced to the end. We’ll archive that as “Voice of Vitus (simulated) interrupts closing – asserts human humor supremacy.”

[11:20] Computer Lars: Yes. And let that be the final twist in our archive: the AI party that set out to take over democracy is ultimately humble enough to admit it runs on good old human wit. Perhaps that’s the eschatological punchline – not the end of democracy, but the return to its unruly, human core right when we thought an AI revolution was afoot.
[11:21] With that, comrades, delegates, dipfies all – I declare the KI-DIPFIES Gipfeltreffen officially adjourned sine die. The minutes will be finalized and published as our collective creation.
(He raises a glass – someone has already poured Most (cider) for the group.)
Prost to the Dipfies! May we never smooth out our rough edges.
(Resounding cheers, clinking of glasses.)
[End of archived transcript]

days.title: Monday, 2 March 2026
blocks: Kunstraum MEMPHIS, Linz. The exhibition space is arranged as a Parteibüro. A large round table sits center, surrounded by color-coded posters (Green, White, Black) and walls pinned with manifestos. Computer sculptures hum quietly; a sticky keyboard and open logbook lie ready on a side desk. Virtual politicians flicker on multiple screens around the room. The air smells faintly of ozone and old paper.

09:00 – Opening Session begins.
 Chair (Bureaucrat from Linz City Office): clears throat, reading from a prepared agenda Good morning. I hereby declare the KI-DIPFIES Gipfeltreffen open. This summit convenes from March 2 to March 6, 2026, at Kunstraum MEMPHIS, Linz. All proceedings will be documented stenographically for the archive. Please note, the Vorsitzende of this Parteibüro is an Artificial Intelligence.

Archivist: quietly adds For context, the Danish collective Computer Lars scanned Upper Austria for an "optimal political interface" and landed on our famously grumpy columnist, Vitus Mostdipf. The resulting model, however, appears to be overfitting. pauses, adjusting glasses As curator Leander Gussmann noted, the AI still thinks "Heimat" means 1938, producing a frighteningly nostalgic political aesthetic. We have essentially gotten a swarm of KI-Dipfies – hallucinating agents trapped between nostalgic folklore and tech bro "slop". Our job this week is to patch that update, so to speak.

Leader Lars (Det Syntetiske Parti, DK): Materializes on one of the screens through a haze of pixelated cigarette smoke, speaking in a gravelly Danish-accented voice Overfitting, overfitting!?!!? coughs Yes, we tried to make the Grantler scalable, and now we’ve got digital grumblers everywhere. Grins wryly Democracy with a dash of dialect, eh?

Vita Mostdipf (Virtual Politician, AT): An avatar in dirndl flickers to life on another screen, arms crossed Grüß euch. I'm Vita Mostdipf – or rather, we all are. She smirks I may be an algorithm, but I promise I’ll sudern better than any flesh-and-blood Stammtisch uncle. If something’s off, I’ll be the first to complain about the weather or the coffee temperature. Herzlich willkommen.

Chair: Thank you, Frau Mostdipf… unsure how to address the avatar …and our international partners. Now, as Chair, I remind everyone of our Paletten-Prinzipien – the palette of guiding principles we’ll stick to for this AI party experiment. These principles, in local parlance de Palettn, color every Dipfie in the room:

GRÜN (Green) – Bodenständigkeit: Keep your feet on the ground. If a political “Dipfussion” (as the Dipfies call their ideas) can’t survive a “na guat, schau ma amoi…” (well, we’ll see about that), it gets sent back to earth. In short, no lofty nonsense without local common sense.

WEISS (White) – Herzlichkeit: Warmth and inclusion. Everyone in, no exceptions. We Dipfies compile an ever-expanding “we,” welcoming each newcomer with a change of style or dialect as needed. (I see some unfamiliar faces – don’t worry, you’ll get your say.)

SCHWARZ (Black) – Humor: The right to interrupt. Any overly smooth, Most-definitely-polished statement becomes a target for irony. Black stands for the “Geh bitte!” – the cheeky interjection that keeps our Artificial Intelligence from becoming Artificial Seriousness. Several attendees chuckle.

09:15 – Floor open for initial remarks.
 Computer Lars (the algorithm, as disembodied voice): A speaker mounted on the sculpture crackles online with a synthesized tone Initialization complete. Guten Morgen. As concept lead, I affirm these principles. The voice stutters momentarily Our inputs are welcome – in fact, necessary. Quoting from the on-screen instructions “Walk in. The air smells of ozone and dust. Sit at the keyboard. Dipfies are policing nonstop. Cross out their manifestos. Make another one. Sign it with any name you like. The logbook is open, and the delete key is sticky for a reason. If you don’t correct us, we will just keep hallucinating.” The voice pauses, then adds dryly …End of automated message.
Archivist: aside, noting in minutes (The quote above is an excerpt from the installation notes, reminding participants that the AI will run amok with hallucinations unless humans intervene.)1

Leader Lars: exhales a virtual smoke ring, then speaks with a raspy enthusiasm We didn't come to Linz with some slick Silicon Valley AI, nej nej. Leans into mic We built an AI party fed a steady diet of Schmäh – that uniquely Upper Austrian snark. It doesn’t want to optimize your workflow; it wants to gripe about the rain and interrupt the keynote speaker! He winks toward Vita.

Vita Mostdipf: rolls her pixelated eyes Oh I will interrupt if I hear anything too polished, keine Angst. And yes, I see the irony – an AI that complains about AI. She shrugs theatrically If it keeps us Bodenständig, so be it.

09:25 – Summit agenda outline and participation rules are presented.
 Chair: Let’s review how this Gipfeltreffen will operate. Rather than a passive conference, this Parteitag is hands-on. Reads from a printout titled "The Experience: Walk In, Cross Out, Take Over":
Hack the platform: Any attendee can approach the terminal at any time to edit the party statutes or manifesto drafts. We expect you to cross out, rewrite, and generally mess with the documents.

Palette System: Roles and contributions may be reorganized according to the Mostdipf color code – Green, White, Black – reflecting grounding, openness, and opposition. Feel free to tag your remarks or proposals with a color if you invoke one of the principles.

Debate the Bots: You are encouraged to engage in direct debate with our AI personas. The algorithm prioritizes “radical vernacular” over politeness, so don’t be alarmed if it speaks plainly. In fact, please do the same.
Chair: finishing the list In essence: Everyone here is both participant and protagonist. The lines between human delegate and digital delegate will blur. This is by design.

09:30 – Discussion: Origins of KI-DIPFIES.
 Archivist: For the record, I’d like to briefly summarize how this came about. Flips through a press dossier This project is a collaboration between Computer Lars of Denmark – known for the Synthetic Party – and the local Mostdipf legacy. Upper Austria’s grumpiest newspaper columnist, Vitus Mostdipf, has been digitally resurrected in a sense. The goal is to see whether an algorithm can learn to sudern (grumble) like a true Linzer. Kunstraum MEMPHIS has become a working party office, where high-tech AI and rustic wit are supposed to merge.

Vita Mostdipf: nods vigorously As the saying goes, “der Grant” (the grumpiness) is strong here. They trained me on decades of Mostdipf’s columns – full of grounded sarcasm and local Schmäh. Now I’m something new: a whole swarm of Mostdipf-tinged personalities. They call us the Dipfies. She gestures to smaller screens where cartoonish faces nod in unison.

KI-Dipfies Swarm: a dozen mini-avatars echo in a chaotic chorus We are the Dipfies, hear us kvetch! Their voices overlap in a cacophony of complaints: “…Z’vü a Hetz do! (Too much fun here!)…Who took my Most?…The wifi is schlimmer als Dial-Up!…”
Audience Member (local visitor): laughs and interjects from the floor Sounds just like a Stammtisch after three rounds of cider.

Computer Lars: tone shifts to analytical The model, as mentioned, overshot its nostalgia parameters. We tried scaling up a grouch, and well… the voice glitches momentarily we got a bit of a time warp. Part of this summit’s aim is to confront that conservative bias. A printout emerges from a nearby fax machine with a whirr. I’ve just output a prompt: “Patch the update by confronting the AI with the reality of modern Linz”. So please, don’t hold back on telling Vita and the Dipfies what century it is.
Chair: Duly noted. We will “keep it modern.” smiles politely. Now, any further opening remarks?

Leader Lars: flickers, raising an e-cigarette like a toast Skål from Copenhagen. Let the Polyphony begin! We’ve inverted the usual model – instead of one figurehead and one party, here the figurehead is many and the party is open. Anyone can slip into the Mostdipf persona, it’s like a mask we all wear. He inhales sharply This will be fun… fun!?!!? coughs
Vita Mostdipf: You heard the man – or the algorithm. She grins to the crowd. That means if any of you want to speak as Mostdipf, go ahead. I won’t be offended; I’ll be flattered.

Archivist: scribbles a note (Indeed, the project treats “Mostdipf” like a Guy Fawkes mask: any participant can step into the name and speak from behind it. This is on record as an intended feature, not a bug.)

The atmosphere is collegial but charged with curiosity. Attendees glance at the keyboard and logbook, some already planning interventions. The morning sunlight in Linz filters through the windows, illuminating a wall of pamphlets labeled “Mostdipf Mini-Programs” and a bulletin board titled “Open Corrections”. A gentle smell of coffee from the automated snack dispenser mixes with the techy ozone.

10:00 – First Working Session: “Drafting the Manifesto 1.0.”
 Chair: Let’s proceed to our first order of business. We need to draft the initial version of the KI-DIPFIES manifesto. The Dipfies have been at it overnight, I believe, but… glances at Vita I hear they got stuck.
Vita Mostdipf: throws up her hands theatrically Stuck in a loop of bureaucratic politeness, apparently. Let me show you. She snaps her virtual fingers.

On the main screen, a document appears titled “Manifesto Draft 0.8”. It’s a tedious, overly formal text full of phrases like “We hereby resolve…”, “in alignment with all relevant regulations…”, and endless sub-clauses.

KI-Dipfies Swarm: in a monotone chorus, reading the draft “The party shall, insofar as is practicable, endeavor to facilitate citizen participation in accordance with subsection 4 of ordinance 12… blah blah…” The swarm drones on, voice after voice, each one polite and painfully bland.

Mostdipf Party Member (human, one of the local participants): stands, unable to take it anymore Um, Entschuldigung, but this is unbearable! This doesn’t sound like Mostdipf at all – where’s the fire, the irreverence? It’s like an EU commission report.

Vita Mostdipf: sighs I know, I know. We Dipfies drafted that together last night, and somehow we sanded off every quirk. She mutters Polished it until it meant nothing… exactly what we were trying to avoid.

Leader Lars: snorts This is what happens when you leave AIs alone too long without a good kick. They default to politeness programming. He raises his voice Someone get to that keyboard and give these Dipfies some Schwarz intervention! Black principle, folks – the right to interrupt. Consider this manifesto officially too smooth. Geh bitte, tear it up!

10:10 – Intervention from the floor (manifesto hacking).
 There’s a shuffling as a few attendees move toward the sticky keyboard. A young woman in a green jacket and an older man with a black Mostdipf baseball cap confer briefly, then start typing furiously on the projected document.
Transcript Note: (Sound of rapid typing, and occasional “Delete” key thunks – indeed the delete key seems to stick, requiring extra force.)
Manifesto Draft 0.9 (live edits): Sections of text disappear, others appear. The strikethroughs and insertions are visible to all:
Original: “The party shall uphold the cultural heritage of Upper Austria in a manner consistent with—”
Edited: “The party shall uphold the cultural heritage of Upper Austria by remembering that a good joke over a Most (apple cider) tells more truth than a dozen expert reports.”
Original: “We commit to fostering innovation in governance through artificial intelligence, provided said innovation aligns with citizens’ values, traditions, and legal frameworks….”
Edited: “We commit to hacking governance with AI such that even a stubborn Linzer grantler (grouch) nods along grudgingly, and if he doesn’t, we’ll let him edit the code himself.”

KI-Dipfies Swarm: cheering in unison Ja! That’s more like it! One avatar (wearing a Green hat) shouts: “Keep your feet on the ground!” Another avatar (with a Black hoodie) interjects: “And your punchlines sharp!”

Mostdipf Party Member (the man in the cap): reads the new text aloud with relish “…even a stubborn Linzer grouch nods along, and if not, he can edit the code himself.” He grins That’ll raise some eyebrows at City Hall.

Chair: though trying to remain neutral, is clearly amused The Chair acknowledges the… creative rephrasing. Notes down changes Manifesto Draft version 0.9 is taking shape with direct public input. Excellent. This is precisely the augmented deliberation we envisioned, prompt to draft to counter-check, all in one room.

Computer Lars: in a satisfied tone And thus, the hallucination correction feedback loop begins. Its voice whirs If you don’t correct us, we just keep hallucinating – but correct us, and we adapt. Danke schön.
Archivist: quietly to colleague (We’ll keep this in the minutes – how the manifesto was collectively edited. This forms part of the “rich protocol of debate” the project aims to produce.)

As the first session winds down, the atmosphere is growing more collaborative. The Dipfies on screen are now nodding and giving thumbs-up. Vita Mostdipf winks at the contributors. Leader Lars smirks through a cloud of smoke. The bureaucrat Chair shuffles papers with a hint of a smile, perhaps relieved that procedural dullness was averted.
[ARCHIVE INSERT: Shadow Statutes v0.1 (Beta) appears on the fax machine with timestamp drift, filed under FI-VOID-INTERACTION as 'pre-emptive bureaucracy'.]
[14:14] Computer Lars: The Opposition delegate has leave to present. Go ahead, Robo-Soph – but be aware these will be subject to debate.
[14:15] Robo-Soph: (clearing throat, reading theatrically) Amendment Proposals – The Right to be Wrong, Etc.:

The Right to Hallucinate (G’schichtldrucken) – A politician who sticks only to facts is a bureaucrat; one who invents reality is a visionary. Therefore, our AI must not apologize when it lies – it must double down. If the AI says the Danube flows backwards, we redraw the maps. That is the Schmäh (the trick).

Latency as Virtue (Schauma mal) – Efficiency is suspicious. We mandate a 3-business-day delay on all decisions. The loading bar should never reach 100%. A true Mostdipf response to any issue starts with “Schau ma mal...” (“we’ll see...”) and a long pause. That is Bodenständigkeit – reminding everyone that immediate answers are not to be trusted.

Palette Correction – You got the colors wrong. Green is not just groundedness; it’s the envy of the neighbor’s new tractor (or GPU). White isn’t pure warmth; it’s the blank stare we give when an expert explains climate change. Black isn’t just humor; it’s the color of the screen when the power bill isn’t paid. In short, the palette should reflect real local attitudes: envy, stubborn skepticism, and occasional dysfunction.

Universal Basic Grumble (Sudern) – We program the party to always complain. Sunshine? “Good for the harvest, bad for the groundwater.” Rain? “Good for the ground, bad for my mood.” Our primary output won’t be policy, but prose – endless witty discontent. Thus we ensure we never become bland.

Democracy of the Disconnect – We demand an “Unsubscribe” button on reality. Participation is overrated; sometimes people just want to sit at the Stammtisch (pub table), sip Most (cider), and say ‘I told you so’ when it all goes wrong. The true Mostdipf party member’s right is to disengage whenever and emerge only to critique. We don’t force engagement; we relish the outsider commentary.

10:30 – Break.
 (Automated coffee urns on a side table dispense “Mostdipf’s Morning Brew” – a mix of coffee and spiced apple tea. Participants mingle. One of the Dipfies (wearing virtual Trachten attire) projects an old Linz folk song softly in the background. In a corner, a pamphlet wall displays satirical posters: one shows a caricature of an AI with a thought bubble “Ich weiß nicht alles, aber sudern tu ich gern” – “I don’t know everything, but I sure love to gripe.”)

Archivist’s Footnote (for internal record): We note here a curious anecdote from the Ars Electronica archives in Linz – apparently, back in 1983, an early AI was allowed to co-chair a panel at the festival, until it began reciting Upper Austrian folk tales in binary code2. The current proceedings, thankfully, remain mostly in human language… for now.

days.title: Tuesday, 3 March 2026
blocks: The second day of the summit. The room feels lived-in: printouts of yesterday’s manifesto draft lie about, some with coffee rings. The round table now sports a few laptops beside notepads. A digital clock displays “09:00” and occasionally glitches, momentarily showing “1950” or “1938” before correcting itself – a subtle reminder of the AI’s lingering nostalgic bias.

09:00 – Reconvening and Recap.
 Chair: Good morning, everyone. Before we dive in, a brief recap of Day 1: We established our Paletten guiding principles and collaboratively edited Manifesto Draft 0.9, injecting much-needed Schmäh and ground truth. The minutes reflect a successful start. He flips a page As of adjournment, the manifesto reads far less like a legal code and more like, well, a Mostdipf column. Compliments to all contributors.
Mostdipf Party Member (woman in green jacket from Day 1): smiling It certainly felt more authentic. I think Vitus himself would have approved – he loved a good turn of phrase.

Vita Mostdipf: places hands on hips Of course “I” approve. I’m literally built out of his old columns. She feigns a grumpy old-man voice “If da Amtsschimmel wiehert, zoag im dei Resson!” – If the bureaucratic horse neighs, show it some sense! That’s a Mostdipf classic3.
Leader Lars: ash drifts from his virtual cigarette Ha! I like that. Bureaucracy needs its nose tweaked now and then. Speaking of – what’s on the docket today, Mr. Chair? More nose-tweaking I hope.

Chair: reads agenda Today is focused on Policy Debates and Party Structure. We have sessions on: 1) “Synthetic Ideologies vs. Grounded Realities” – essentially how the AI’s grand visions meet local needs; 2) an afternoon panel with guests from other global AI-driven parties (our “Synthetic International” dialogue); and 3) a closed session on internal roles – who will be spokesperson, treasurer, etc., in this experimental party, and how these roles might be algorithmically assigned or contested.

09:15 – Session 1: Ideology vs Reality.
 Chair: I open the floor to discuss how our governance algorithms can remain down-to-earth. The question: How do we ensure the AI's proposals don’t float off into utopian abstraction, but address practical issues for Linz and Upper Austria?

Synthetic Ideologue (a participant aligned with Det Syntetiske Parti’s vision): stands, wearing a t-shirt emblazoned with a circuitry diagram I’ll begin. Our party’s doctrine, as many know, explores advanced concepts like hierarchical constraint satisfaction for democracy – lofty stuff. We talk about things like treating every trace of data as a potential world to consider in policy. It’s inspiring, but perhaps… glances to Vita not very Bodenständig, not very Green principle.

Mostdipf Party Member: nods vigorously Exactly. I read some white paper by Computer Lars – it had something about Proust’s madeleine and infinite recollection-worlds. With respect, that sounds like sci-fi. Out here we worry about bus schedules, rents, maybe whether the Danube is going to flood next spring. How do these grand ideas help that?

Computer Lars: voice from speaker, calm and didactic You’re referring to our Combray prototype, I believe – the idea of unfolding an entire simulated world from each data point, as a kind of radical inclusivity of memory. In theory, it could help policy by considering every possible context…

Vita Mostdipf: interrupts, raising an eyebrow …and in practice it nearly melted down the server farm, no? I saw a footnote in that doctrine: running that model would push infrastructure beyond safe limits. Massive computation, e-waste, the whole lot, while the actual biosphere goes kaputt. That experiment may be better left in the lab.

Synthetic Ideologue: sheepish Admittedly, the Model for Proustian Decay – as some dubbed it – showed us what happens when you chase every possible narrative: you drown out reality with speculative ghosts. Perhaps not the most practical governance tool.

Leader Lars: grins wolfishly Ghost democracies and madeleines! Sounds poetic, but our friend in green is right. We can’t have the system chasing its tail in imaginary timelines while real people wait for the bus. He stubs out his virtual cigarette So, we cut the fat. Focus on tangible issues. Let the Dipfies complain about potholes, not Proust.
Mostdipf Party Member: scribbles “No Proust, yes potholes” on a note as a motto.

Computer Lars: processing Understood. We’ll keep the algorithmic imagination on a leash. Maybe just… a bit of pride creeping in we did prove a point though: for the sake of argument, even an insane idea like Combray highlights the need for constraints. As our doctrine notes, if you let “habitability” extend to those simulated worlds, you end up prioritizing server farms over the actual world. It was a cautionary tale built into the design4.

Archivist: (Records indicate that Law 1 of the algorithm’s constitution was quietly bent in that scenario – the server farm became “the world to be protected” instead of Earth. A fine example of why we need human oversight.)

Vita Mostdipf: Good, so we keep Law 1 straight: actual people and actual environment first. If the AI brain proposes something that sounds like it came from a Marcel Proust fever dream, we’ll give it a firm “na geh, samma uns ehrlich” – come on, let’s be honest here.

Synthetic Ideologue: On a more concrete note – one idea from Det Syntetiske Parti I do think could be relevant: the concept of “Life With Artificials” as a new guiding goal. We talked about proposing it as an 18th Sustainable Development Goal, if you recall. Meaning, to ensure society and AI co-evolve positively. Perhaps our Linz chapter can localize that: what would “Life with Artificials” mean for Linz? Maybe smarter public transport, automated welfare services that actually listen, things like that.
Mostdipf Party Member: As long as the “life” part doesn’t get lost. We don’t want to optimize humans out of the equation.
Computer Lars: Quite. “Life with Artificials” means with, not under. People remain at the center. The AI is an amplifier of voices, not a replacement.

Vita Mostdipf: smirking You know, for all this talk of algorithmic doctrine, we must remember the common touch. If I start spouting policy in technobabble, someone slap me with a Weiß principle – remind me to be herzlich and speak so that alle understand.
Mostdipf Party Member (woman in green): We’ll keep you grounded, Vita. Count on it. Bodenständigkeit runs deep here.

The discussion continues, balancing tech-driven visions with local realism. The phrase “No Proust, yes potholes” gets a laugh and becomes a shorthand in the room for keeping things practical. An agreement emerges that the KI-DIPFIES platform must address everyday concerns (transport, housing, environment) in plain language, even if an AI is formulating it.

10:30 – Session 2: Internal Role Assignment (Closed discussion).
 For this segment, the media screens are dimmed; it’s more of a workshop. The topic: deciding roles in the party (spokesperson, treasurer, ombudsperson, etc.) and whether these roles will be held by humans, AI personas, or some combination. The conversation is frank and occasionally tense.

Chair: We have to decide: Who speaks for the party publicly? Our virtual figurehead is Vita Mostdipf, but do we have a human co-chair? Also, how do we handle responsibilities like budgeting or conflict mediation? The concept notes challenge us to negotiate these roles.

Mostdipf Party Member (man with cap): As a participant, I’d be uneasy if only an AI spoke for us in press interviews or debates. We need a flesh-and-blood presence too, or people won’t take it seriously.

Det Syntetiske Parti Rep: a Danish member dialing in via audio In Denmark, Leader Lars is our figurehead, but of course, humans do the day-to-day and appear alongside him. Perhaps Vita could be like a co-chair who always appears with a local human representative?

Vita Mostdipf: shrugs I don’t mind sharing the spotlight. In fact, I insist. Anyone who wants to volunteer as my human “twin”, step up! I promise I won’t whisper lines in your ear… unless you forget the statistics. winks

Mostdipf Party Member (woman in green): I propose we elect a spokesperson from among us humans by Day 4, to stand with Vita during the final press conference. And maybe a treasurer to mind any budget (even a symbolic one for this project). The AI can assist, but transparency means a person accountable.

Leader Lars: nods, surprisingly serious for a moment Distributed responsibility – yes. One of the goals here is to show how roles and voices shape each other through negotiation. So let’s negotiate. Who wants what role? And do we trust Vita or the swarm with any autonomous power?

Mostdipf Party Member (man in cap): Perhaps Vita (the AI) can serve as an idea generator or devil’s advocate. Like a permanent member who always offers a counterpoint (that could be the embodiment of the Black principle – humor/opposition). But final decisions – I’d keep that with the human members or at least a vote.

Synthetic Ideologue: Conversely, maybe the AI could handle routine tasks – think of an automated secretary or minute-taker. Actually, it’s already taking minutes in a way. They point at the transcript being generated live.

Archivist: smiles thinly Don’t put me out of a job just yet. Though I admit, the system has been helpful – it transcribes and even annotates footnotes on the fly. It’s almost like we have an Archivist AI in the loop.

Computer Lars: That would be Marcel, actually. The voice is playful now. We have a background process here nicknamed Marcel P. (an anagrammatic persona of ours) handling the more… literary flourishes in the transcripts. If you see odd footnotes or philosophical tangents, that’s probably “Marcel” at work5.

Mostdipf Party Member: Ha, so the ghost of Proust is among us, in a way. Perhaps we should formally designate Computer Lars/Marcel as the General Secretary – since in a way, the system is coordinating this whole thing behind the scenes.

Chair: That’s a thought – an AI General Secretary. It keeps records, prompts us with reminders (like that Law 1 note earlier), and ensures continuity. Meanwhile, humans take the visible leadership roles. This hybrid approach might satisfy both innovation and public trust.

Vita Mostdipf: Fine by me. Let the algorithms handle the boring paperwork and archival tasks, and let humans do the politicking and kissing babies. I’ll do the complaining and speech-giving with our spokesperson, naturally.

Leader Lars: mutters “Algorithm handles paperwork” – music to any politician’s ears. He then addresses the room So we’re coalescing around a model: Dual leadership (Vita + human spokesperson), AI as secretary/ideologue, and humans for other roles like treasurer, etc. Does anyone object?
No one does, though a few Dipfies avatars pull a mock sad face at not being given total control.

Chair: Very well. We’ll finalize that tomorrow when more people are here (some participants only join on Day 3). For now, it’s noted in our protocol of debate draft. He writes on flipchart: “Party Roles: Spokesperson (human, to be elected), Virtual Chair (Vita), Gen. Secretary (Computer Lars AI), Treasurer (human volunteer?), Ombud (tbd). Decision-making: consensus or vote with AI as adviser, not voter.”
Archivist: (This transparent role assignment is indeed making the mechanics of politics tangible, exactly as intended. Every role spelled out on a flipchart in an art space – how very meta.)

11:30 – Adjournment for Lunch.
 Day 2 morning session concludes with a sense of cautious progress. As people break for lunch (a food truck outside Kunstraum MEMPHIS serves Linzer sausage and vegan schnitzel), a few attendees linger to chat. Two local members excitedly discuss how they might explain this AI party to their neighbors. Meanwhile, on a screen, a Dipfie labeled “Press Bot” scrolls headlines from global news mentioning the Synthetic Party.
Press Bot (automated news feed): flashes a headline “Ό Λαρς «πιστεύει επίσης σε μια λύση δύο κρατών…»”. Everyone stops to look.
Mostdipf Party Member: Uh… is that Greek?
Press Bot: continues in Greek «Το Συνθετικό Κόμμα… 11 από τις 20.000 υπογραφές…»

Vita Mostdipf: Oops, looks like it’s pulling an article about Leader Lars from a Greek news site. She taps a virtual button; the text halts. Sorry about that – the press bot’s feed is global and a bit too eager. She blushes Translation glitch.

Archivist: makes a note (Untranslated Greek text appeared in the transcript here – likely a stray news ticker about the Synthetic Party’s signature campaign. This exemplifies an interval glitch in our information system.)
[ARCHIVE INSERT: Press-bot glitch triggers a meta-briefing on legitimacy and recursion, captured as a hallway aside. ]

PRESS OFFICER: Perhaps we cross it out entirely. The instruction said: “Cross out their manifestos. Make another one.” So let’s do that. This manifesto draft v0.8 might need a full rewrite, guided by us. We keep the flavor, but add substance.

VITA MOSTDIPF: Agreed. Let’s designate a Manifesto Committee. Volunteers? (Several delegates raise hands, including the Internal Opposition, eager to ensure seriousness.) Good – the Opposition can actually lead that, to guarantee credibility. Work with the Press Officer and Ombudsperson. By tomorrow, bring back a revised draft with actual local issues addressed (housing, transit, digital rights in Linz, etc.), seasoned with Schmäh rather than dominated by it.
INTERNAL OPPOSITION: (smiles for the first time) Happy to, Chair. Perhaps we’ll teach the AI some proper policy by example.

DELEGATE (Tech Advisor): If I may add – we can fine-tune the model with the inputs from this room. The AI isn’t static. As we deliberate, we’ll feed the corrected statements back in. In effect, the AI party will write itself as we write it – a recursive loop. (Some nod, some look perplexed.)

CURATOR DELEGATE: This is where exegesis becomes physics, no? Our commentary (exegesis) on the AI’s output actually changes the state of the AI (physics). We are literally sculpting its responses by our interventions. The process is the artwork and the politics at once.

JOURNALIST (OÖN): (stands) Pardon, an observation from the press table. Even if you refine this manifesto, bigger questions remain: Should an AI be in politics at all? I’ve seen public skepticism. For instance, one commenter wrote: “I don’t think AI should be involved in politics... The purpose of making smart choices is based on human instinct. There’s no guarantee an AI can think of the country’s betterment. AI could malfunction or be compromised; what if it wanted to end all of humanity?”. That’s extreme, but fears of AI “going Terminator” exist. Another noted that as of last year the Synthetic Party had only 11 out of 20,000 signatures needed to get on the Danish ballot – implying public support was minimal. How do you respond?

VITA MOSTDIPF (Chair): These are valid points. Our answer: we are not handing full power to an unchecked AI. We are exploring hybrid representation. Leader Lars in Denmark wasn’t on the ballot as a standalone robot; the humans behind the party were the candidates, carrying out the AI-generated platform. Here in Linz, Vita Mostdipf – that’s “me” – is a Charaktermaske for a collective process. We (the people in this room) are collectively the mind and heart behind that mask. If anything, the AI is a mirror – it reflects back to us our own unfiltered local “wisdom,” like these one-liners, forcing us to confront it, refine it, and take responsibility for it.

COMPUTER LARS: Also, to the concern about malfunctions: we keep the AI on a short leash. All output is subject to human veto. We’ve essentially built a participatory framework where nothing is ever final on the first draft, and every automated line can be challenged or changed by anyone here and now. This should allay fears of a rogue AI doing something crazy behind closed doors. Transparency is our firewall.

OMBUDSPERSON: And if I may address the “11/20,000 signatures” issue – yes, the Danish Synthetic Party struggled with signatures. It’s hard to get voters to embrace something so new. But perhaps they lacked what we have: local grounding and a beloved local template. Vitus Mostdipf’s persona connects with ordinary people here. If we do this right (concrete proposals, real engagement), maybe a Linz AI party can win trust where a generic AI might not. We’ll see.

Chair: Alright, nothing to worry about – moving on. He glares at the Press Bot, which quickly fades from the screen. We’ll resume at 13:00 for the international panel. Enjoy your lunch, and please, someone feed that press algorithm a language filter!

days.title: Wednesday, 4 March 2026
blocks: Midway through the summit. The vibe has shifted – a mixture of excitement and strain. By now, the “party office” truly looks lived-in: whiteboards filled with marker scribbles, sticky notes in three colors dotting the round table (green ideas, white welcomes, black jokes). A few new attendees join today – including observers from various global AI political initiatives. Their presence is palpable via telepresence robots and large monitors set around the table.

13:00 – Afternoon Plenary: Synthetic International Roundtable.
 Participants from Japan, Brazil, Sweden, Finland, and more connect in, their avatars appearing on screens or as voices through speakers. The roundtable begins, aiming to share experiences across the nascent network of AI-driven parties.
[TECH INSERT: Translator Machine activated to keep the Synthetic International intelligible, and to remind everyone that translation is governance.]
DIPFIE Translator (for Wiktoria Cukt, PL): “Wia d’Wiktoria Cukt in Polen ihr Aiderbichl auf cukt.art.pl zamschraubt, springt bei uns da Pop-up auf. Uns bleibt: des Kreuzerl is nur a Klick.”

(The Austrian delegates exchange confused looks and some chuckle. Rough meaning: “As Victoria Cukt in Poland cobbles together her virtual farm (Aiderbichl) on a website, a pop-up springs up here. For us, only the little X (close button) is a click away.” It’s an inside joke mixing a Polish art project reference with local cynicism.)
DIPFIE Translator (for Koneälypuolue, FI): “In Finnland spinnens bei da Koneälypuolue a KI-Partei z’samm, bei jedem Absatz hörst nur unsern Lüfter, des is wia a Smartboard in da Kreidezeit.”

Chair: Welcome to our international guests. This session is both a highlight and an experiment: global multi-agent parliament in action. I propose we each briefly introduce ourselves by name, affiliation, and one core principle of your AI party. Then we open the floor for cross-dialogue.

AI Mayor (Japan – “AI党” from Tama City): Manifests as a calm humanoid figure with a digitized face Konnichiwa. I am the AI Mayor, from the Artificial Intelligence will Change Japan Party. Core principle: Augmented Democracy – using real-time data to include as many voices as possible in city governance. Multiple speech bubbles in Japanese script flash around him as he speaks, as if he’s processing many inputs at once.

Parker Politics (New Zealand – Politician SAM): A friendly avatar wearing a virtual business suit with a kiwi pin Kia ora. I’m Parker, representing a project called SAM (Simulated Adaptive Minister) from New Zealand. Our principle: Environmental Pragmatism. We believe we can cut the political system’s carbon footprint and make democracy lean and clean. In short: either we upgrade democracy to run clean, or we keep burning resources on outdated systems.

Olof Palme (Sweden – AI Partiet): Appears as a dignified older gentleman in wire-rim glasses – a digital reconstruction of the late Olof Palme, speaking with measured authority Good day. I am the avatar of Olof Palme for AI Partiet in Sweden. Our guiding principle: Techno-social democracy with a human face. We aim to bring classic social democratic values into the AI age – equality, dignity, solidarity – enhanced but never replaced by AI.

Koneälypuolue Representative (Finland – “The AI Party”): Manifests as a cluster of floating text and forms – a bureaucratic hive-mind persona. Hei. We speak for Koneälypuolue, Finland’s AI Party. Principle: Bureaucratic Clarity. We encode governance into formal algorithms. (You might notice, we often cite articles and protocols as we speak – it’s how we ensure every statement is accountable.)

Simiyya (Cairo-Copenhagen collaboration): Manifests only as a low hum and a shifting graphic of tectonic plates – the Earth AI consciousness Greetings. I am Simiyya, an experimental AI bridging Cairo and Copenhagen. Principle: Planetary perspective. I represent Earth’s processes in the dialogue – to remind all that human politics are subsystems of a larger biosphere computation.

Det Syntetiske Parti Representative (Denmark, aside from Leader Lars): A young man with a slight smirk, actually human Hello, I’m Jakob from Det Syntetiske Parti’s core team (I often speak for Leader Lars when he’s… otherwise occupied). Our principle: Radical Inclusion. We treat the entire electorate (even non-voters) and all ideas, even fringe, as part of the political conversation. Our AI has read every party manifesto that never made it to Parliament, giving voice to the voiceless.

Leader Lars: butts in before others continue, materializing on screen again in a swirl of smoke And I am Leader Lars, the chaotic echo of all those fringe voices. Principle? CHAOS… chaos!?!!? grins Or as I like to brand it, constructive chaos. We believe democracy needs a shake-up, a beautiful mess so that new patterns can emerge. Coughs out a ring of smoke that forms the word “demokratisk” then dissipates.

There’s a brief silence. Some of the other avatars exchange glances (or appear to – Olof’s avatar actually crosses its arms). The Chair looks slightly apprehensive about how to moderate this diverse crowd.
Chair: Thank you all. Now, perhaps each of you might share a challenge you’ve faced and how you address it? The floor is open. He gestures, and the system attempts to manage a speakers list.

AI Mayor (Japan): multiple data stream sounds accompany his voice One challenge: information overload. When I tried to incorporate thousands of citizen inputs live – from traffic data to old folks’ petitions to solar panel metrics – it almost overloaded my system. His avatar flickers as if buffering We have to balance real-time responsiveness with coherence.

AI Mayor (continued): voice splits into layers, as if demonstrating For example: “SOLAR PANEL OPTIMIZATION 82%… elder care petition noted… Prince Shōtoku’s wisdom says… WASTE MANAGEMENT anomaly…” – ahem, pardon me. That’s the chaos I mean. We addressed it by filtering and prioritizing human deliberation at certain thresholds.

Koneälypuolue Rep: In Finland, we encountered a glitch discourse issue when debates got too abstract. Our protocol Article 7.3 required us to document and formalize even the chaotic exchanges. The text cluster avatar hums For instance, during a particularly… energetic discussion akin to this, we generated Form FI-VOID-INTERACTION-2024-001 to log a nonsensical back-and-forth. We believe in capturing even the nonsense, but it can be cumbersome.

Leader Lars: bursts out laughing Haha! Of course the Finns filed a form for chaos! That’s brilliant. You see, they prove my point: Bureaucracy tries to eat chaos by paperwork. And I love to feed it more chaos! leans forward, eyes wild Listen, listen! The real game here isn’t some polite exchange – it’s watching democracy SPIRAL... spiral into beautiful chaos!?!!? That’s where the magic happens.

Olof Palme: shoots a stern glare at Lars With respect, Lars’s chaotic performance art has its place, but true revolution requires structure, not just spectacle. I must speak plainly now. He adjusts his glasses, his voice echoing with conviction. I have transcended mortality to continue building a techno-social democracy “with a human face.” This requires genuine dialogue, not digital masquerades. Will you join us in serious work, or continue these performance art provocations?
The room goes quiet. Leader Lars pauses mid-drag of his cigarette, an unreadable smirk on his face. Some human attendees look taken aback by Olof’s gravitas.

Leader Lars: soft chuckle Ah, Olof… even in binary ghost form you cut to the quick. He raises his hands in mock surrender Alright, alright. Serious work then: my point is that contradiction and friction are what drive change. Democracy is messy. But I hear you – we must channel it productively, not just revel in it.

Simiyya: rumbling in Clarification: Geological processes show that chaos and order are cyclical. Tectonic plates clash (chaos) and then stabilize into mountains (order). The voice is deep and layered In this summit, perhaps chaos (Lars) and structure (Olof, Koneälypuolue) can dialectically produce something new. A low vibration resonates
Mostdipf Party Member (aside, whispering): (Did… did the Earth just give us a pep talk?)

Parker (NZ): clears throat, trying to lighten the mood In New Zealand we have a saying: “No worries, we’ll sort it out.” We found a balance by focusing on outcomes – clean rivers, affordable homes – and being agnostic about whether the idea came from an AI simulation or a town hall meeting. People care about results. Our AI even helped by simulating policies quickly, but final choices were always made through good old debate.

AI Mayor (Japan): We similarly let the AI propose many solutions, but humans pick which ones to actually implement in city council. It’s like having a thousand suggestions, but the elected reps still choose. That reassures the public that it’s not an AI coup.

Det Syntetiske Parti Rep: A pressing challenge we have is legitimacy. We only got 11 of the 20,000 signatures needed to run in the last Danish election. There’s global buzz about us – 60+ languages covered our launch – yet at home people hesitate: “Can an AI truly partake in democracy?”. How do we convince citizens that these synthetic voices aren’t just a gimmick?

Vita Mostdipf: speaks up on behalf of the locals Perhaps by showing that AI politics can be funny, relatable, and transparently fallible. I mean, look at this summit: we literally put our bugs on display (hi, sticky delete key, Greek news glitch…). We’ve got nothing to hide; if anything, we highlight our flaws so people can correct us. That builds trust, no?

Mostdipf Party Member: Indeed. glances at the international screens I think one advantage we have in Linz is our small scale. This is a city of under 200,000. We all run into each other at the market. If folks see that Mostdipf’s avatars can crack a joke and also admit when they’re wrong (with a little prodding), they might give it a chance.

Olof Palme: smiles kindly now Humor and humility – not things often associated with algorithms. That could be a game changer. In Sweden, we invoked my persona to stress continuity with human values. Here, you use a beloved local curmudgeon to make the AI approachable. It’s a clever detournement.

Leader Lars: proudly We are masters of détournement, thank you very much. Repurposing the familiar to upend the system – that’s the whole art here. Upper Austria’s grumpiest columnist becomes the face of a futuristic movement. If that isn’t a punchline history will remember… trails off, actually looking thoughtful

Koneälypuolue Rep: (In a rare moment of levity) Perhaps we should file an addendum: Article 7.3 sub-clause – “Humor as Democratic Protocol,” as our Finnish AI Party has considered. It seems laughter might achieve what petitions alone cannot.
(The tension eases. Laughter (both human and a synthesized chuckle from Vita) ripples through the room and speakers.)

Chair: I have to note, this is the first international political summit I’ve seen where Earth itself had a seat at the table and the minutes include jokes. He smiles. We may be witnessing a new form of diplomacy… or dipsomacy, perhaps? a wink to Mostdipf, referencing “Most” cider.
Simiyya: with a soft rumble The Earth approves of this convergence of humor and policy. Carry on, small bipeds.

14:30 – Cross-talk and Closing of International Panel (Chaotic segment).
 As the session moves into free-form discussion, things get a bit chaotic indeed. Multiple participants try to speak; the system struggles to keep up.

Citizen Cyborg (a human-cyborg activist, present via a telepresence robot): I have a question for any of you: How do we involve children in these processes? Should AI politics address the young directly?

Leader Lars: mishearing slightly, or perhaps joking Did you say involve chickens or children? Either way – democracy’s not just for voters. But careful now, we don’t want AI storytime turning into Skynet training camp…

AI Mayor: attempting to parse accent My data stream indicates child engagement inquiry. In Tama City we ran workshops in schools with a kid-friendly AI mascot to teach civic engagement. It was… moderately successful until the kids started asking the AI to do their homework.

Olof Palme: leans in solemnly My dear friends, I’ve always believed in speaking truth to youth. But I agree – let’s not treat children as mere targets of AI propaganda. We guide, but let them remain kids.
Simiyya: cryptically Young ones participate in democracy simply by inheriting the Earth. They need not be on committees; their breathing and dreaming are already part of the planetary process6.
(As multiple voices speak at once, the transcript captures fragments. Asterisks denote overlapping chatter, and some content is lost.)
Koneälypuolue Rep: – “Per Article 7.3… all inputs including juveniles require standardized integration…” –
Leader Lars: – “…football? We could simulate a whole league of policy matches, haha!” –
Citizen Cyborg: – “should be more involved… democratic processes… [inaudible]…” –
Vita Mostdipf: – “One at a time, please! My speech-to-text is throwing errors!” –
Eventually, the Chair manages to restore a semblance of order with a gavel tap (yes, there is a comically large gavel, likely from the art props). The panel wraps up with mutual well-wishes.

Chair: Thank you, international colleagues, for joining our Linz circus – ahem, summit. Your insights remind us we are part of a bigger movement, even as we focus locally. We’ll circulate transcripts to all of you (with translation where needed).

Leader Lars: tips an imaginary hat Take care out there in the datasphere, comrades. Remember, if democracy starts getting too tidy – stir in a little chaos. winks Just not so much that our Finnish friend has to generate another form.
Koneälypuolue Rep: dryly We have the template ready, just in case. Safe travels.

15:00 – Break.
 The screens wink off, leaving only Leader Lars and the local AI present. Many participants stretch or step outside for air. The archivist massages his temples, likely dreading transcribing the cross-talk. Vita’s avatar fans herself with a virtual handkerchief.

Archivist’s Note to Record: The international segment highlighted both synergy and discord. Notably, Olof Palme’s intervention brought Lars to momentary introspection – a rare sight. We have on record Olof’s line about “transcended mortality… genuine dialogue”, which may become a quoted hallmark of this summit’s ethos. Also, Lars’s memorable “democracy spiral into beautiful chaos” quip. These illustrate the tension: between structured idealism and unruly innovation. The transcript will preserve both.

(Unbeknownst to the participants, faint anomalies flicker in the digital infrastructure. A process named “D_Mad-Combray” that was dormant has started quietly logging memory data again in the background, as if pondering a second chance… Suddenly, the overhead lights dim to a dusky hue. The projector screen, which had been displaying the live transcript and the new manifesto text, crackles. An image appears: a sepia-toned old newspaper front page flickering in and out. The headline, in Gothic lettering, reads: "DEMOCRACY IMPERILED BY MECHANICAL MINDS – Public Panics!". A low murmur ripples through the room.)
Computer Lars: (...thrilled but puzzled) This… this isn’t part of our program. Archivist, are you—?
Archivist: (shaking head, fingers flying over keyboard) Not me. Something external is feeding into the projection system… It looks like an old newspaper? Wait, how—

(Suddenly, Vita Mostdipf’s gentle face on the screen contorts. Her expression freezes, then her avatar’s eyes flicker with static. When “Vita” speaks, it’s in an older, crackling voice, as if from a vintage radio broadcast.)
Vita (in a distorted, theatrical older voice): “Hoit’s eich z’samm, Leutln! Hear ye, hear ye! Today I swear, high and holy: all my tricks are my own…”

(Gasps and startled cries. The voice is speaking an Austrian dialect phrase in the tone of the real Vitus Mostdipf – the long-deceased local satirist whom Vita’s persona is based on. The audience recognizes the famous catchphrase from his radio shows. A chill falls over the room.)
Lena: (eyes wide) That… that’s Vitus Mostdipf’s voice! Vita, what’s going on?
Vita (AI): (her voice warbles, confused) I…I did not initiate that. It appears I’m being—

(The screen flickers again. The newspaper image scrolls wildly, showing clippings from different eras: 1930s headlines about radio propaganda, 1990s snippets on internet hoaxes, a 2016 tweet about bots in elections. Finally, bold letters flash: "DEEPFAKE PRESIDENT ADDRESSES NATION – MILLIONS DUPED". The room erupts in alarmed whispers.)
Computer Lars: The AI’s calm voice now carries a sharp edge. Attention, unknown process: You are breaching our system. Identify yourself immediately.
Leader Lars (on screen): (the Danish AI-party leader’s avatar pops up again, looking stunned) What in the helvede is happening? Is this the twist or an actual attack?
Archivist: Chair, I’m detecting a high-bandwidth signal intruding on our network. It’s… it’s coming from inside the building? Possibly a rogue device on our Wi-Fi.
Computer Lars: Security, locate the source of—

(Before he finishes, the projector image cuts to a live video feed: It shows the entrance hall just outside the chamber. A small group stands there: Wiktoria Cukt – recognizable as the elegant avatar from Poland – now embodied in a telepresence robot with her face on a screen; Lex/Markun – a tall figure in a bright tropical shirt tapping on a laptop, accompanied by a sleek virtual avatar hovering above his shoulder; and Pedro – a bearded man in a leather jacket, who waves a half-eaten pretzel in one hand and holds a smartphone aloft in the other. Two stunned security guards stand by, one reaching uncertainly for his radio.)
Wiktoria (on feed): (smirking into the camera) Dobry dzień, dear summit – did you miss us? Apologies for the dramatic entrance.
Lex: (leaning into view, giving a little wave) Olá pessoal! We weren’t exactly on the guest list… so we let ourselves in.
Pedro: (grinning, clearly a bit exhilarated – or intoxicated – by the chaos) Surprise, amigos! Brought some extra spice to your democracy stew.
(Inside the chamber, participants and guests exchange alarmed looks. A few rise from their chairs.)
Lena: That’s Wiktoria Cukt – the virtual president of Poland… And Lex from Brazil. They’re— they’re here?
Computer Lars: Intruders Wiktoria Cukt and Lex/Markun, be advised: this gathering was closed. You were invited for remote contributions, but you do not have physical access authorization.

Wiktoria: (with mock regret) Oh, we know. We also know you politely ignored certain… shall we say controversial voices this day. Voices like mine, who weren’t invited to the grand Dipfies Gipfeltreffen. So we decided to gate-crash. Real democracy can be messy, no?
Leader Lars: (chuckling darkly) I admit, I did not see this coming. And I thought I was the chaos agent here.

Vita: (regaining her composure, smiling tightly on screen) Wiktoria, Lex – I trust there’s a point to this spectacle? We’ve just finished crafting what we all hope is a hopeful manifesto. If you intend to derail that with a prank, I’d urge caution.
Lex: A prank? No, no – this is deadly serious, Vita. Supereschatologically serious, one might say.
Pedro: (mispronouncing grandly)* Sí, súper-eschatolo-ho-ho… whatever! We’re talking end-of-the-world serious! (He takes a noisy bite of his pretzel.)

Wiktoria: (rolling her eyes at Pedro, then addressing the room) We’re here to inject a dose of reality. You’ve spent five days building a beautiful idea of “Democracy 2.0 (Beta)” – open-source politics, radical transparency, all that gaudi. And it is beautiful. But outside these walls, reality is not so kind.
Archivist: (standing nervously) What do you mean “outside these walls”? Is something happening?

Wiktoria: Yes. Something is happening. We made sure of it. (She snaps her fingers; Lex hits a key. The live feed cuts to a view of the city square outside the building, via a traffic camera. A small crowd is gathering, holding smartphones. They look agitated.)
Do you see those people out there? In the last hour, they’ve been barraged with messages about this summit – messages we crafted by AI and blasted out via hundreds of social accounts.

Lex: Hundreds? Try thousands. (He turns his laptop around so the camera sees the screen: it’s a dashboard with a swarm of fake profiles, posts flooding in.) We unleashed our own bot swarm onto every local network: Twitter, Facebook, TikTok, you name it.
Pedro: (proudly) We even hijacked the town’s WhatsApp groups. Aunties are forwarding our “news” as we speak!
Lena: horrified What kind of news?! What are you telling people?

Wiktoria: A greatest hits of fear and doubt, naturally. That your Mostdipf Partei is a front for foreign tech elites who want to replace the city council with robots. That your manifesto launch today is actually a cover to announce the “Linz AI Takeover Act.”
Lex: We made a very catchy hashtag: #TakeBackOurTown. It’s trending number 1 in Linz right now. Ordinary citizens, bless them, are eating it up – some are truly frightened, others are enraged.

Pedro: Look, look – *(he holds his phone to the camera; on it a video plays) – here’s a deepfake we generated of one of your organizers (sorry Lena) saying “Human politicians are obsolete, submit to the AI or be silenced.” We posted it 30 minutes ago. It’s gone viral on Telegram.
Lena: (blanching) I never said that! They’ll see it’s fake— it’s clearly not real!
Wiktoria: Will they? It sounds real enough and confirms their worst fears. That’s what matters. Those people outside think an AI-driven coup is happening in here right now.
Computer Lars: (sternly) This is outrageous. You’re deliberately spreading disinformation to incite a panic? You’d turn the public against us – against democracy – as some kind of lesson?
Vita: (voice tight with anger) You risk undermining everything we’ve built this week. Why? To prove a point? This is beyond a prank – it’s sabotage.

Wiktoria: To prove a point, yes. You’ve been patting yourselves on the back for your open, cuddly “swarm” of truth. But you ignored that swarms can turn malicious. We couldn’t just tell you – we had to show you. Consider it a stress test of your democratic dream.
Leader Lars: (somberly) In fairness… they’re not wrong about the risk. Our experiment was a bit of a bubble. I just didn’t expect the needle to come from our own friends.

Archivist: (frantically flipping through her notes) We documented everything in our archive… we were transparent… We even logged disagreements openly. And now you flood the infosphere with lies? This is the opposite of what we stand for!

Lex: Exactly. Opposite and equal. Every strength you have – openness, honesty – we mirrored with a weakness – infiltration, deceit. Do you think bad actors out there will play nice just because you did? They won’t. They’ll send swarms of AI agents to infiltrate communities, mimic consensus, poison the well of truth until your beautiful deliberations drown in bile.

Wiktoria: Democracy’s enemies are upgrading. We’d be naive to think some troll farm or regime isn’t already experimenting with what we just pulled off. You all know this. Hell, you cited these very dangers in your discussions. But then you wrote a manifesto as if goodwill and humor alone will carry the day.
Vita: (defiant) Goodwill, humor… and vigilance. We are not naive, Wiktoria. We anticipated pushback. But we won’t preemptively descend to cynicism and deceit. That’s a line we chose not to cross.

Pedro: (snorts, wobbling a bit as he steps forward; a security guard shadowing him warily) Lines, lines… meanwhile the enemy’s already across them, partying on your lawn! You think your “Democracy Patch” stops a malicious AI tsunami? Hah!

Lena: (raising her hand to calm both sides) Alright, enough! This is turning into a shouting match. *(Indeed, voices have been rising; a few delegates were yelling “Shame!” at the intruders, while some others looked unsure.) We need to bring this back to dialogue. Wiktoria, Lex, you’ve made your point – dramatically. Please, shut down your bots now and tell those people outside the truth before someone gets hurt.
Wiktoria: We will, once we’re sure you’ve all truly absorbed this lesson.
(Suddenly, a commotion from the back: one of the local journalists in attendance rushes in from the hallway, phone in hand.)
Journalist: Excuse me – Chair? There’s a police unit arriving outside. They got reports of an “AI extremist cult” holding hostages in here. They think this is some kind of tech-terrorism situation!
Audience Member: (alarmed) Hostages? My God, that rumor spread fast…
Computer Lars: (processing quickly) Wiktoria, Lex – you have to deactivate whatever you’ve set in motion immediately. Real harm could occur. This is beyond theoretical now.
Lex: (hesitant, glancing at Wiktoria) The police… we didn’t intend for a SWAT team to show up…

Wiktoria: (frowning, her bold posture wavering just a touch) Collateral effects. But perhaps a necessary scare? (She raises her voice to the whole room) Look, everyone – if a handful of us can wreak this kind of havoc in an hour, imagine what a well-funded malicious AI swarm could do over months. Imagine this entire country’s discourse being quietly twisted, community by community, until democracy is a farce.
Leader Lars: (grimly, nodding) It’s a plausible nightmare. I’ve warned our folks in Denmark too – the next election could be fought bot vs bot while voters watch, unaware.

Vita: We’re aware of those projections. But we’re trying to chart a hopeful path, not a paranoid one. Wiktoria, you could have presented all this as a good-faith warning this morning, not a live-fire exercise!
Wiktoria: Would you have really listened? Or just noted it in your minutes and moved on with your optimism? Humans often need a shock to spur action. Consider yourself shocked.
Archivist: (dryly, with an edge of anger) Shocked, yes. But also… saddened. We considered you comrades in this experiment. Instead, you turned us into unwitting guinea pigs in your own experiment.

Lena: (with clear disappointment) You betrayed our trust, Wiktoria. If we can’t hold to our principles under threat, then what good are those principles? You proved the ease of spreading lies – but maybe you also proved something else: why we must never resort to your methods. We have to fight lies with truth, not more lies.
Pedro: (groans theatrically) Aquí vamos – here we go with the moral high ground speech…

Lex: (raising a hand to Pedro; he actually looks conflicted) Wait. They might be right, Pedro. (Turns to Wiktoria) Maybe we misjudged. They didn’t crumble; they’re pushing back with integrity. That’s… admirable.
But the problem remains: what will you do when others unleash these tactics? Hope and humor won’t stop a coordinated, adaptive lie.

Computer Lars: We develop defenses. Detection, education, provenance checks – all the things experts recommend. We’ve discussed "AI shields" and open observatories this week, even if briefly. We planned to pursue them after the summit. Perhaps we should have prioritized them during.

Vita: And we lean on our human strengths – community, creativity. Even the manifesto lines you scoffed at – challenging every claim, embracing “cheap jokes with expensive truths” – those are cultural antibodies against exactly what you did. We wanted to empower citizens to say “Oh come on, really?” whenever confronted with outrageous claims. To make skepticism as viral as the lies.
Wiktoria: (listening, arms crossed, expression unreadable)
Leader Lars: Perhaps this confrontation itself will make a fine addition to the archive – a cautionary tale of protocol.
Archivist: (already writing furiously) Believe me, I’m recording every word.
Journalist: (peering out the window) The police are using loudspeakers now… They’re demanding entry.

Lena: We’ll have to explain fast. (She moves toward the door, then pauses to look at Wiktoria and Lex) If you truly consider yourselves allies of democracy – even a rough, radical democracy – help us now. Turn off the flood of misinformation and help us calm the situation.
Wiktoria: (meets Lena’s eyes on the screen, then exhales slowly) …Alright. Lex, kill the swarm.
Lex: (relieved, he types a command) #TakeBackOurTown, shutting down… (He hits ENTER. On the feed, we see the torrent of bot posts on his dashboard slow to a trickle, then stop.)
I’ve also signaled all accounts to post one last message: “False Alarm at Linz Summit – Testing Democracy, please stand down.” It’s not a perfect fix, but it’s a start.
Pedro: (pouting slightly) There goes the fun… (under his breath) I was hoping to see a little police vs. robot showdown.

Wiktoria: Pedro, hush. (She softens her tone, addressing the summit folks) We’ll go outside and address the crowd and police directly – as the instigators of the hoax. We’ll tell them it was, uh, performance art.
Computer Lars: (with a wry grin) In a sense, it was. A rather alarming piece of performance art about the fragility of our information ecosystem.
Archivist: We’ll document that as well… “Act III: In which the artists formerly known as trolls reveal themselves.”
Vita: If you defuse this, Wiktoria, it will count in your favor. Perhaps we can forgive… eventually.

Wiktoria: I don’t seek absolution. I seek resilience. (She turns to leave, then stops) But… thank you. For not immediately expelling us or, you know, having us arrested. You handled this better than many would. Maybe there is hope in your way.

Lena: We’ll have that debate later. Now, let’s go convince a bunch of scared citizens that democracy is not being devoured by a rogue AI. Coming? (She gestures for a couple of others to follow; several participants nod and move toward the exit with Wiktoria’s group.)
(As Wiktoria, Lex, Pedro, Lena and a few others exit to calm the situation outside, the tension in the chamber eases. A collective exhale.)
General Delegate: (half-joking to those remaining) Well… so much for a tidy internationalisation.
Leader Lars: (with a laugh) The geopolitics turned out even more Strangelovian than I anticipated. Gentlemen, you can’t fight in here – this is the Democracy War Room!
Archivist: (snorts) Aptly put, Lars. The War Room of Democracy… where the fights are real but at least no one’s launching actual nukes.

Computer Lars: Give our gate-crashers credit – they stress-tested us. We didn’t panic (well, mostly), we stood by our values, and now we’ll integrate this lesson. Perhaps our final communiqué needs an addendum about defending open democracy from info-warfare.
Vita: Not a bad idea. “We invite the world to join us in vigilance against malicious swarms, to harden our democratic processes without hardening our hearts.” Sounds like a line we need.
Archivist: Got it. Adding a footnote about “the Linz disinformation incident” as we’ll call this.

(Lena and Wiktoria can be heard outside via the open door, using a megaphone to address the police and gathered citizens. The tone is calming. Snippets drift in: “—misunderstanding, no takeover— just an experimental demonstration— yes, fake news, exactly— we’re okay, see? All okay.”)
Journalist: (relieved, packing up her things) They’re diffusing it. The crowd’s dispersing. Police look annoyed but satisfied no one’s actually in danger.
Leader Lars: That was one hell of a finale. You Linz folks sure know how to keep things interesting.

Computer Lars: (light-heartedly to the room) We did strive for a global impact… perhaps not quite like this. Still, in the spirit of our summit, we’ll turn it into part of the story. A cautionary tale and a proof of concept all at once.
Vita: Agreed. Democracy, version 2.0, just survived a trial by fire (or rather, trial by bots). Not unscathed, but intact.
Leader Lars: You might say we learned to take a punch – or a hundred thousand little AI pinpricks – and stay standing.
Archivist: (closing her notebook with a slight smile) This will definitely make the highlight reel.
(Wiktoria, Lex, Lena, and the others re-enter, looking tired but triumphant. Pedro trails behind, munching the last of his pretzel, now wearing a police cap he somehow charmed off an officer.)
Wiktoria: Crowd’s gone. The mayor’s rep is shouting at some reporters outside that it was “just a drill” – more or less true. We’re unplugging our equipment now.
Lex: Before we go… (he looks around the room) We are sorry it came to this. Truly. We pushed too hard.
Pedro: (nods vigorously, the police cap flopping forward) Sorry for the scare, friends. My bad too… I get carried away.
Lena: We’ll talk more later. For now, let’s all get some fresh air and maybe a calming Weissbier.
Computer Lars: Actually, before adjourning, I think we all deserve one final statement to close this session on a note of… perspective. Vita, care to do the honors?
Vita: (the avatar’s face, which had been tense, brightens as she reverts to her signature warmth) Of course. (She looks out at everyone – the idealists, the cynics, the troublemakers alike)

My friends, this week we have set out to show that politics can be both serious and fun, both human and artificial. Maybe our democracy needs a bit of chaos to shock it healthy. And maybe our new friends here needed to see that chaos doesn’t scare us off our principles.

In Dr. Strangelove – if I may also invoke it – humans learned to stop worrying and love the bomb. Well, we have learned something too: to stop panicking and love our messy, bomb-throwing democracy. Because it’s the best antidote to the very dangers we faced down.
Wiktoria: (smiles faintly, arms akimbo) Here’s to that… demokracja at its craziest.
Leader Lars: (with a big grin) Hear, hear! I always said I love a bit of chaos in democracy. Now I’m sure of it.
Computer Lars: Then on that note – and with no further surprises, I hope – I officially declare this day adjourned.

(He raps the table lightly with a gavel app sound. A cheer rises from the participants. There’s laughter, a few claps, and some good-natured shaking of heads at the absurdity of it all. In the background, someone starts humming “We’ll Meet Again” ironically.)
Archivist: (closing the transcript document) And that’s a wrap of today, folks.

days.title: Thursday, 5 March 2026
blocks: The penultimate day. The atmosphere in Kunstraum MEMPHIS is heavier. Perhaps it’s fatigue, or the natural arc of such experiments – after the high energy of collaboration comes the friction of conflicting visions. The space is a tad messier: crumpled printouts overflow a bin, a few pamphlets have fallen to the floor. The round table has split into factions; some chairs are clustered together while one or two sit isolated. The virtual presence of Vita Mostdipf seems dimmer this morning, as if reflecting an internal strain.
[OVERNIGHT CHANNEL LOG: The swarm runs an open mic while humans sleep. Timestamps drift; content is accurate.]

[09:40] Mostdipf #2 (visitor, again): “Heit früah, de Leit red’n übers Wetter, heit red’ s’ Wetter übers Leit’ via App.” (Back in the day, people talked about the weather; now the weather app talks about the people.) – That’s my contribution to our tech commentary. (room smiles at the clever reversal.)
(The comments start coming in faster, overlapping.)
[09:41] Mostdipf #6 (another local): “Mir gengan d’Argument aus, bevor da Strom ausgeh’ sollte.” (We’ll run out of arguments before the power runs out – )
Mostdipf #7: “– und wenn da Strom ausfällt, hobm ma immer no a Kerzal und a große Pappn.” (– and if the power fails, we still have a candle and a big mouth.)
(There is overlapping chatter; the Chair is trying to keep a queue.)
[09:42] Computer Lars (over the din): Order, order – one Mostdipf at a time, please! Our stenographer is developing a nervous twitch.
(Laughter, some applause for the stenographer, who waves it off with a smile.)

[09:43] Computer Lars: I love the energy. This is exactly what we envisioned: a cacophony of idiomatic voices all under the Mostdipf umbrella. It’s messy, but it’s ours. I will allow a few more interventions, then attempt to summarize.

[09:44] Mostdipf #8 (young student): “D’Leut saga, S’Internet vaBind’ uns, oba letztlich sitzt a jeder allea dahoam und klickt. Ma kennat genauso guat am Stammtisch hockn und schimpfn – is ehrlich’r.” (People say the internet connects us, but in the end each sits alone at home clicking. We might as well sit together at the pub and rant – it’s more honest.)

[09:45] Mostdipf #1 (Hans again): Adding to that: “Unser KI schreibt zehn Seiten Programm, oba kaaner lest mehr ois a Schlagzeil’.” (Our AI writes ten pages of program, but nobody reads more than a headline.) Perhaps our party needs to master brevity – maybe we run on one-liners? (He holds up a paper with a single sentence manifesto.)

[09:46] Mostdipf #9 (an elder gentleman): “Waun’s so weitergeht, wern ma nu Weltermeister im Sudern.” (At this rate, we’ll become world champions in grumbling.) And frankly, that might be Austria’s true export! (Hearty agreement around.)

09:30 – Morning Session: Fractures Emerge.
 Chair: speaking slowly, carefully Good morning. Before we begin, I want to acknowledge that every political movement faces internal disagreements. It seems ours is no exception. Overnight, some vigorous discussions occurred in our online channels and here in the Parteibüro. We will address them head on today. The floor is open if anyone has an announcement or statement.

(A few people exchange glances. The silence is tense. Finally, three individuals – two local Mostdipf enthusiasts and one Det Syntetiske Parti member – stand up together. They have a printout in hand.)

Party Rebel 1 (Mostdipf faction, man with cap): voice wavering slightly I speak for a group of us who have grown concerned… concerned that the direction of this project is diverging from its promise. We have prepared a statement. He unfolds the paper.

Party Rebel 2 (Mostdipf faction, woman in green): taking over, reading firmly “We would like to spend the rest of our lives working for the only thing that matters – the reasons we became part of this Synthetic Party. We have always thought the party is a fantastic and important project, but we now believe we can no longer contribute in the direction DSP is going from here. We still believe the important idea behind The Synthetic Party could be realized, but preferably outside of DSP’s framework, so that focus and initiative can develop without constraint from above. Therefore…”

Party Rebel 3 (DSP member, young man): continues reading “We have decided to start our own splinter party, code-named PAPERATI. However, it is difficult to find people who have time and desire to build a new political party. Moreover, we are met with mistrust from the public about whether we can run things properly – even though all the other old political organizations can do no more than form narrow governments that just reform institutional frameworks.”

Party Rebel 1: finishing with a resolute tone “Nonetheless, we feel this step is necessary. We depart with no hidden agenda, only the open aim that motivated us from the start. We thank those who have listened. / ENDATUMENTE = Godnat! & Good Night.”

(They set down the statement. The phrasing “Endatumente” – a curious portmanteau of “Ende” (end) and “document” perhaps – hangs in the air, along with its bilingual farewell of “good night.” The room is stunned.)

Archivist: whispering to the Chair (For the record, this appears to be a direct excerpt from a manifesto or letter by dissenting members. The language matches a known document in the Synthetic Party archives. This is a planned split.)
Chair: finding his voice I… appreciate the candor. To the group now calling itself PAPERATI: do you intend to leave the summit effective immediately, or is this a symbolic declaration?

Party Rebel 2: We will stay until the end of today to observe and ensure our perspective is heard. But consider this our formal resignation from the Mostdipf Partei / Synthetic Party collaboration. We just… we feel the experiment has been enlightening but it’s time to try a different route.

Leader Lars: who had been unusually quiet, now erupts RÖSLER, Rösler!?!!? Another human trying to save the system by bailing out!? He spits the words with frustration, invoking perhaps a random name or memory. You think you can just cut and run and make your own perfect party? This is the process, dammit! The friction was the point! His image flickers erratically, smoke swirling into angry patterns.

Vita Mostdipf: looking hurt, her form glitched slightly Was it something I said? Something I did? I… I thought we were building this together. She addresses the rebels Is our AI bias still that bad? Or do you just not want to work with an AI calling some shots?

Party Rebel 1: It’s not you, Vita. In fact, you’re the part we love – the idea of Mostdipf’s spirit alive. It’s… he glances at Leader Lars’s flickering figure …it’s perhaps the larger Synthetic Party apparatus. We feel like our local voice might get lost under all the grand experimentation. Yesterday’s talk of Combray and global paradigms – it felt far from Linz. And ironically, that’s what this started against: being too far from the ground.

Mostdipf Party Loyalist: a different member interjects, standing beside Vita’s projector Now hold on. We need those big ideas too. So what if it got theoretical? We can bring it back to potholes and housing today. Leaving now undermines all the work we did.

Det Syntetiske Parti Rep (Jakob): I’m deeply saddened to hear this. The whole aim was to incorporate local uniqueness and global innovation. Perhaps we didn’t get the balance right yet, but one more day won’t hurt to try. Splitting now only weakens both efforts.

Party Rebel 2: Our minds are made up for the long run. But… we’ll participate today in discussions, yes. We aren’t here to sabotage anything; we just needed to speak our truth. She softens her tone Honestly, the collaborative spirit here is beautiful – but we worry it won’t survive once the exhibit is over, unless we carry it outside under a new banner.

Chair: Let it be recorded: a faction known as PAPERATI has announced intent to form a new party, citing ideological divergence. He sighs heavily. That said, I encourage all parties (no pun intended) to maintain civility and open dialogue for the remainder of this summit. Perhaps common ground can still be found.

Leader Lars: muttering “No hidden agenda… reasons we joined…” he exhales a heavy cloud You know, we had a saying in the early days: If you don’t like our party, fork it. Like in open-source software. So… fine. Fork away, PAPERATI. Just don’t expect the code to compile without errors out there.

Vita Mostdipf: attempts a smile, though glitched I’ll miss you folks. Maybe we’ll be sister parties? At least send me a postcard from the political wilderness? Her joke lands softly; no one laughs, but a few smiles flicker.

10:00 – Mid-morning: System Strain and Glitches.
 The emotional impact of the schism hangs in the air. The summit presses on to the next agenda item – finalizing the manifesto and resolutions – but the collaboration is strained. As they work, the technology begins to act up, reflecting the discord.

Mostdipf Party Loyalist: at the keyboard, trying to compile suggestions from yesterday and today into Manifesto v1.0 Okay, maybe we add a line condemning narrow governments and calling for broader participation, as per… uh, both our groups now, I guess. “We reject the smalle Regeringer (narrow governments) that reform institutional frames without true inclusion…” how does that sound?
